DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR F. L. O'KEEFE, AM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives expresses its deep regret at the death on Friday, 21 April 1989, of Mr Frank Lionel O'Keefe, AM, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Paterson from 1969 to 1984, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to the members of his family in their bereavement.

Frank O'Keefe was born on 6 October 1912 at Petersham, New South Wales, and grew up in the Rose Bay area of Sydney; but as a young man, having been transferred by his employers to Gunnedah, decided to make that his home. In the decades that followed Frank O'Keefe contributed greatly to the growth and development of Gunnedah. In all, he served in the area of local government for 43 years and was mayor from 1948 to 1949 and from 1953 to 1969. He was also the civil defence controller for 30 years. In 1944 Frank O'Keefe married Alice Doreen Pascoe-Nan-to whom he often, as we know, paid tribute as his constant ally.

Frank O'Keefe entered Federal Parliament in 1969 representing the seat of Paterson and remained until his retirement in 1984. During his time in the House he was a member of various Commonwealth delegations and he served as a member of several committees. Frank O'Keefe's interests in Parliament were numerous, but regularly centred on the harsh reality of life in the bush. Within his electorate Frank O'Keefe knew the devastation of both floods and droughts. He spoke strongly for those who suffered from these natural disasters.

Apart from his service to both Federal and local government, he had an abiding interest in many sports and participated with flair in swimming, tennis and cricket. Throughout his life Frank O'Keefe gave enthusiastically to the community around him. On behalf of the Government I extend to his family our condolences in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Liberal Party I join the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in expressing our sympathy to the relatives of the late Frank O'Keefe. I knew Frank O'Keefe as a fellow parliamentarian for some 10 years. During that time and after Frank retired from Parliament I saw him often at the Sydney Cricket Ground and at cricket and football fixtures. He had a very deep love not only of his country and his Party but also of the people of Gunnedah whom he served for so long. He had the distinction of being the Mayor of Gunnedah and a member of the Shire Council at the same time as being, first, the State member and subsequently the Federal member. He also had a very deep love of sport and of Australian sporting achievements. One often found Frank O'Keefe present at sporting gatherings.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways Frank epitomised the values, the attitudes and the principles of people in the bush in New South Wales. He was the essence of the old Country Party, which subsequently became the National Party in New South Wales. He stood very firmly for its values. All of us in the Liberal Party liked him immensely. We admired the fortitude he displayed at times of illness and setbacks during his life. I know I speak for all members of the Liberal Party who knew and served with Frank O'Keefe in the New South Wales Parliament when he was the member for Upper Hunter and, subsequently, in this national Parliament, when I extend to his family our sympathy in their bereavement and record the quiet, loyal years of service that he gave to his Party and his country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in the motion of condolence moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). In so doing, I thank the Prime Minister for the courtesy of allowing me to say something in this House in memory of Frank O'Keefe. Frank O'Keefe, as much as anyone I have ever known, epitomised a giant in a small community. He was one of the leading citizens of a town which he espoused as his own, the town of Gunnedah in north-west New South Wales. In the 1950s Gunnedah was stagnant. Through Frank O'Keefe's initiatives, enthusiasm and effort, it became quite a vigorous community. Indeed, it was through his effort that the Gunnedah abattoir was established, and for a great deal of his life he was chairman of that meatworks, one of the major exporting works in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: His own term of service was quite extraordinary. He served eight years in the New South Wales Legislature, 15 years in the Federal Parliament, 43 years in local government, 18 years as mayor, and seven years as deputy mayor. For 50 years he served Australia. He served it well, he served it with devotion, he served it with application, and he always served it with good humour. In his youth, Frank O'Keefe was a remarkable sport. He was a good cricketer and a good tennis player. He claimed that through sport he gained entry into politics. In his adult years he gave back a great deal to the sports of his youth by becoming an administrator. He was an official in rugby league, cricket and tennis in the north-west; he certainly contributed as much to as he ever gained from sport.

As to his own community, I think one could best describe him as Mr Gunnedah, for throughout the whole of his life Mr O'Keefe contributed a great deal to that town's development and future, and I know that everyone in that community regarded him very much as one of their own. To Nan, his widow, on behalf of my colleagues, my wife Rosemary and myself, I extend my deepest sympathy. His widow, Nan, has lost a great friend, Gunnedah has lost a great citizen, and Australia has lost a great contributor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Frank O'Keefe was a champion tennis player, a champion cricket player and a champion bloke. He was respected by all who knew him. —I refer the Prime Minister to recent media reports that the New Zealand Prime Minister's speech last week at Yale University, in which he called the ANZUS Treaty a `dead letter', had been faxed to the Australian High Commission in Wellington the day before its delivery and that the Minister for Defence had received prior notice of Mr Lange's intended speech. Will the Prime Minister confirm that his Government received advance knowledge of the speech; if so, what actions did the Government take on behalf of Australia to convey its deep concern at the contents of that speech to the New Zealand Government as the third Treaty partner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of wider consultations, I understand that we were informed in advance by New Zealand that Mr Lange would be making a speech at Yale. The discussions were informal and not based on any proposed text. The possibility that Mr Lange might refer to the withdrawal from the ANZUS Council was referred to as an option rather than a firm proposal. We stressed Australia's continued support for the ANZUS Treaty; our hope for the resumption of its trilateral character and for its maintenance as the basis of the bilateral defence relationship with New Zealand; and our concern that no action be taken to complicate this.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition has raised the question, I go beyond the immediate point of what relationship, if any, there was with us prior to the delivery of that speech to make quite clear our position on this issue. I have read Mr Lange's speech at Yale University last week in which he, as Prime Minister of New Zealand, described New Zealand's views on defence issues and their strategic setting. Without attempting a comprehensive analysis of the speech that was delivered by the New Zealand Prime Minister, it is perfectly clear to everybody, including, I imagine, the Leader of the Opposition, that this Government takes a quite different view on some important issues addressed in that speech. In particular, let me say unequivocally that this Government sees ship visits as a natural part of our alliance relationship with the United States-an alliance which not only directly enhances Australia's security, including our conventional security, but also forms part of a Western alliance framework underpinning global security.

The speech of the New Zealand Prime Minister does not address these wider considerations. Our differences with New Zealand on this issue are well known and, of course, they are well known to the Government of New Zealand. The Prime Minister of New Zealand in his speech did not then announce a decision to withdraw from the ANZUS Council but rather, as honourable members will see from reading the speech, raised that as a possibility. Obviously, while ultimately that would be a matter for the Government of New Zealand to decide, it also is an issue which affects the other two parties to the treaty. For that reason, it is one on which it is appropriate for Australia to state a view. I state the view quite clearly: it is our hope that New Zealand will not withdraw from the Council. That would be a further symbolic step by New Zealand away from ANZUS, complicating our bilateral defence cooperation with New Zealand, which is currently based upon ANZUS, and making harder a restoration of trilateral cooperation should New Zealand ever change its policy on ship visits. We believe, as indeed does the United States, that there is a major benefit in defence cooperation between Australia and New Zealand. It is our wish and our intention that that should continue.

Importantly, I emphasise that as a matter of international law-it is important that this be noted-withdrawal by New Zealand from the Council would not affect the treaty arrangements between Australia and the United States. Moreover, as a matter of our foreign and defence policies, we remain totally committed to that alliance relationship. I should add also, in view of comments and media coverage in recent days, that whatever interests Australia has to pursue with the United States in the trade field and whatever differences we have there-we do have some substantial differences in that area-the close harmony of Australian and American foreign policy and defence interests remains unaffected.

I think that from the answer I have given it is obvious that we were not aware in advance-although there had been some broad indications, in the terms I have given, of the contents of the speech-that the Prime Minister may be moving to that sort of area. Having said that, we have made quite clear all the way through our fundamental difference with our friends in New Zealand on this issue. Repeating in conclusion, I hope that the Government of New Zealand will not go to this final step of withdrawing from the treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims that only age pensioners well enough to work will benefit from the increase in the tax free area announced in the April economic statement? Can the Minister advise the House of the validity of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hawker for that question. I think all honourable members in the House will have an interest in the answer in the sense that, whenever there is change either in social security incomes tests or in the tax treatment of income affecting age pensions, there is invariably some confusion. I think it is important that I clarify the position. Honourable members will be aware that we have carried out an extensive process of consultation. One of the issues that became crystal clear was that pensioners were concerned about the interaction between the income test and the tax treatment of income. Therefore, in response to that concern we decided to make pensions income test free in the area of $40 a week for single pensioners and $70 a week combined for married couples. Income in those areas will be 100 per cent tax free. This radical objective will be obtained in 1989-90 for married couples and 1990-91 for single pensioners. It will boost the after tax income for the vast majority of age pensioners.

ANSWER.PARA: Some commentators have claimed that this move will benefit only a limited number of age pensioners who are well enough to secure part time work. Of course, that is quite incorrect. The free area does not simply go to earned income from paid employment; it covers, in fact, all relevant income received by age pensioners, such as interest from investments, superannuation pensions, overseas pensions and rental income as well as earnings from paid employment. Out of 1.3 million age pensioners, 1.15 million report some such income. By 1991 the pension free area will be, as I said, 100 per cent tax free. More than three-quarters of all age pensioners receive private non-pension income less than the free area and therefore will not have to pay income tax from 1990-91.

As a result of this historic reform more than one million age pensioners will face no tax at all on their interest from investments or on their superannuation pensions or, indeed, on their income from any source. For the vast majority of age pensioners we have made the recent debate about the tax treatment of income from investments absolutely irrelevant. It will be irrelevant to them because we have delivered a more far-reaching reform. We have taken them out of the tax system and made their interest income tax free if their non-pension income in 1990-91 is below the pension free area.

Let us consider the example of a single age pensioner whose only private non-pension income comes from interest from investments. In 1989-90, these people will be able to receive up to $25 per week and still receive the full pension and pay no tax. In 1990-91, this amount will increase to $40 per week. With a savings bank savings investment account paying 12 per cent per annum interest, such a pensioner can invest up to $10,800 next financial year and $17,300 in 1990-91 without losing any pension or paying any tax. Age pensioners with several thousand dollars in cheque accounts or in a 3.5 per cent passbook account now have a real incentive to maximise their investment income.

The gains from the Government's April statement tax measures for age pensioners are not restricted to those with private non-pension income below the free areas. In fact, the combined operation of the pensioner tax rebate and the reduction in tax rates means that those pensioners still paying tax will also receive a significant boost in their after tax income. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does Australia continue to seek a total ban on chemical weapons, or will the International Conference on Chemical Weapons, to be held in Australia later this year, divert the negotiations to the much weaker goal of non-proliferation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for this question, which deals with a matter of quite fundamental importance not only to this country but to the whole world. I can assure the honourable member that a comprehensive global ban on chemical weapons remains Australia's prime objective in this area of disarmament. We are very active participants in the United Nations Committee on Disarmament's negotiations on a chemical weapons convention and we are fully committed to the early conclusion, and entry into force, of an effective convention. The honourable gentleman may know what a prominent role Australia is playing in international efforts against chemical weapons. Indeed, I think it is fair to say that no country is playing a more prominent role in this area than Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me substantiate that claim. Firstly, we are active in convening consultations among 19 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development member states-indeed, that group is known as the Australian group-to develop coordinated export controls over chemical weapons precursors. Secondly, we have been very active in undertaking consultations with governments in the region to prevent the spread of chemical weapons in our neighbourhood. Thirdly, we have been active in building a constructive working dialogue with Australia's own chemical industry.

It is against that background of consistent effort in this area of trying to move towards the complete obliteration of chemical weapons that Australia will host a major international chemical weapons conference in September this year. The aim of that conference will be to bring together governments and representatives of the international chemical industry to discuss, within such an environment, the role and the responsibility of industry in the international movement to eradicate chemical weapons and, in particular, to discuss the contribution that industry can make towards a comprehensive global ban on chemical weapons. This government-industry conference that we will convene in September is intended to support fully and to make a constructive weapons convention. Obviously, industry will have a crucial role to play if the chemical weapons convention is to be effective. The conference will provide a dialogue between governments and industry on the problem of chemical weapons, the implications for industry of a chemical weapons convention, and the ways in which industry itself can make a contribution to a comprehensive convention.

In conclusion, Australians should be proud of the obviously prominent and almost pre-eminent role that the Australian Government, on behalf of the people of Australia, is playing in this important area of disarmament. The conference will not be in any way an attempt to establish what could be called a second track alternative to the chemical weapons convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just want your dreams to come true.

—Is the Minister for Defence aware of recent claims by Senator Julian McGauran that the Government plans to swallow the Bendigo Ordnance Factory in a merger with the Maribyrnong Ordnance Factory? Are these claims correct? Will the Minister confirm that, under this Government, the Bendigo Ordnance Factory has a strong and secure future located in Bendigo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. The question has an interesting base to it, given the fact that the Leader of the Opposition likes to set himself bogus tests, such as whether he can get a National Party bloke on a Liberal Party ticket, as though that matters a damn to the country, and fails every test when it comes to dealing with the organisation of efficiencies, be they in government industry or in terms of sensible deregulation in some areas of the economy, where it actually matters. That is where it does matter. Yet another example of that is the process by which the National Party and the Liberal Party seem to be attempting to take the seat from the honourable gentleman who asked the question, an activity they will never succeed in. They have spent a substantial amount of time, via the senator he mentioned, attacking the honourable member on totally bogus grounds about developments at the factory in Bendigo.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make a couple of points absolutely clear, to answer the nonsense that has been put forward, unrepudiated, by the Opposition in regard to the efficiencies that have been undertaken by this Government at the factory in Bendigo. The first thing I would point out is that the factory will not be swallowed up by the Maribyrnong Ordnance Factory. Claims to that effect have no foundation whatsoever. Under this Government, the Bendigo factory has a strong and secure future. When we took office Bendigo was under-equipped, uncompetitive and heavily subsidised, like all other areas of industry in the Defence portfolio. Bendigo can now face a future with confidence, contrary to what has been said by Senator McGauran, because it has been rendered efficient. At the time we took office defence factories either had to be reformed or closed. What members of the National Party would choose for Bendigo would be a slow death. The Government chooses reform so that we have industries which will grow and jobs which will last.

The fact of the matter is that in government factories in the defence area where there have been substantial micro-economic reforms there has been a very substantial shift in the numbers of people working. They have come down from about 14,000 to about 8,000. All this dramatic change has been negotiated with the unions around the country. In absolute terms the factories are producing a great deal more than they were before. Net savings to the Defence portfolio to date are somewhere in the realm of $200m to $260m per annum, which is the equivalent of more than 3 per cent real growth in the defence vote, which is the way in which we are able to afford the defence programs we are putting forward in a period of very tight constraint. The only way we can afford defence expenditure in a period of restraint is by taking efficiencies.

One can pick any point of government activity anywhere and find that, when a government takes a tough decision, puts it through, makes the organisation survive, makes it effective and commercial, one can guarantee it will be subject to nitpicking by the Opposition-in this case, Senator McGauran-along the way. If ever the coalition gets on to this side of the House-and I do not believe it will-any of its reform efforts will collapse precisely because of the same nitpicking. Indeed, Senator McGauran himself said, when queried on the micro-economic reform issues that were confronting the coalition at the time:

The Liberal Party, from time to time, always try and bully the National Party but it never works because our strength comes from our membership . . . and they'll never be able to bully our membership.

That is the problem in this country. We have an Opposition trying to sell its whole platform now on the basis that it is capable of delivering on micro-economic reform. The Opposition will fail to jump any test it confronts on this.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to recent reports suggesting that nuclear fusion experiments have taken place at room temperature using a relatively simple process? Can he inform the House of any attempts his Department has made to corroborate such reports? What would such a breakthrough mean?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least six groups in Australia at the moment are carrying out experimentation on cold fusion. They include two divisions of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)-the divisions of mineral products and fuel technology-and the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. Universities in Melbourne, Sydney and Adelaide-particularly, Flinders University-are also carrying out work. At this stage there are still some difficulties with cold fusion and alternative explanations for the appearance of heat and neutrons are possible.

ANSWER.PARA: This follows initial reports of two very interesting experiments in the State of Utah. First was the work of Pons and Fleischmann, which now has a bit of a question mark over it. It is thought that there are alternative chemical explanations for what was reported. More interesting work is being carried out in Utah by a group at the Brigham Young University at Provo led by Dr Steven Jones, who is no relation of mine! His work is perhaps the most interesting because it helps to explain a phenomenon in geomorphology-that the earth is getting hotter in some areas, as shown by volcanic action. It also provides a possible explanation for the phenomenon of continental drift.

What Jones's people have found with their work on cold fusion is that there appears to be interaction between atoms of deuterium and deuterium. It is thought that deuterium, which occurs naturally in sea water, is sucked in through fissures in the shore, and goes into the magma inside the earth. There is then a cold fusion process. I say `cold fusion' because it is operating at thousands of degrees celsius, not at millions of degrees celsius as is the case with fusion work in laboratories. Then out comes heat, helium and tritium. This accounts for the extraordinary phenomena which occurred a few years ago and were not understood. Tritium is a radioactive isotope of hydrogen which occurs as a by-product of hydrogen bomb tests. There have been a number of observations of tritium in the atmosphere in the presence of volcanoes. It was assumed that this was as a result of Soviet nuclear testing and that the tritium was borne on winds from this testing. The alternative explanation is that it was a result of a fusion process.

One last point needs to be made: I congratulate Australian industry, which has not normally been interested in long term research, for the very generous contribution by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd laboratories. It has made a down payment of $60,000 towards CSIRO research on cold fusion, with the prospect that if the experimentation looks promising there will be continued support. We have to maintain a certain scientific scepticism; we cannot go overboard about cold fusion because there is still a big question mark over it. However, if this development is correct it makes the splitting of the uranium atom in 1938 pale into insignificance. We cannot afford not to be deeply involved, because the political and socio-economic implications are enormous.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is he aware of reports that several Australian health care workers have contracted the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) through occupational transmission of the virus? Can he inform honourable members whether these reports are accurate? What steps are being taken to protect health care workers from contracting the AIDS virus?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I realise that this issue is causing considerable concern amongst health care workers and the general community. Regrettably, much of this concern arises from misinformation and confusion in the media. I want to put the facts clearly on the record. Media reports have dealt with two separate cases, neither of which relates to known infection of a professional health care worker as a result of occupational exposure to the AIDS virus. I understand that the case which was reported in the Newcastle Herald relates to a needle-stick injury suffered by a nurse which has not been confirmed to have resulted in infection; thus no details have been reported to me, the Department of Community Services and Health or the National Health and Medical Research Council special unit on AIDS epidemiology and clinical research.

ANSWER.PARA: The second case, reported by Professor Basten at the recent doctors summit on AIDS, involves a woman who, in the course of helping to care for a friend suffering from AIDS, received a needle-stick injury and was infected with the virus. The woman was not a health care worker and the incident did not take place in a hospital or health care setting but at the man's place of residence. I do not seek to undermine either the seriousness or the tragic nature of that incident. I think it is a tragic reinforcement of the need for all health workers, volunteers and carers who are helping AIDS patients strictly to adhere to guidelines on infection control and accident prevention. It is important to clarify that there is, as yet, no known case of a professional health care worker in Australia having been infected as a result of occupational exposure. Nevertheless, the risk does exist, and it is of understandable concern to the many people caring for AIDS sufferers with skill, dedication and compassion. Last week's doctors summit on AIDS addressed this issue at some length, during which medical and scientific experts stressed the continuing efficacy of infection control guidelines, developed in consultation with the medical profession, and reached general consensus that there was no basis for, and it would be impracticable to introduce, compulsory testing for all surgical patients. The Australian Medical Association's new policy on testing of patients is to be commended, demonstrating a responsible, commonsense approach based on medical and scientific advice and designed to protect the public health of the whole community.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr N.A. Brown interjecting-

ANSWER.PARA: Mr N.A. Brown interjecting-

ANSWER.PARA: The gains are undeniable. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The devastating effects of the Hawke Government's policy of forcing home loan interest rates to their highest level in history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is on record as a government which has broken two national records. First, never in Australia's history have homes been less affordable than they are today; and, secondly, never in Australia's history-not since Federation-have home loan interest rates been as high as they are today. When one looks at the statistics on home affordability, one can see that they really do tell a terrible story and are an indictment of the Hawke Government. The Housing Industry Association's March quarterly survey, which came out just a few days ago, shows that for yet another quarter home affordability has continued to slide. The article concerning the survey states:
The most recent fall occurred across nearly all States-
actually, the only exception was Canberra-
and reflected the increase in housing interest rates during the March quarter.
The article made this very telling point:

Although incomes increased faster than house prices, this improvement was overshadowed by a one per cent increase in housing interest rates to 15.5 per cent by mid-quarter which caused the Housing Affordability Index to decline by 5.1 per cent.

Those figures do not show the effect of yet another half a per cent increase in the home loan interest rates on top of that, taking it to 16 per cent. So even those figures on home affordability are too optimistic because, since those figures were collated, home affordability has declined still further.

One of the tragedies of these figures is the way in which in a city like Sydney, which has been particularly hard hit, there has been some turning in the marketplace and housing prices have started to decline. Incomes have risen slightly during the past quarter but, even though house prices have declined and incomes have risen, the fact is that the increase in home loan interest rates has far outstripped the positive effects of the fall in house prices, and even in Sydney with those effects home affordability has continued to decline. If one looks at the Real Estate Institute's recent survey, one will see that it comes up with similar sorts of figures. One of the things that it points out-and I think that this is particularly poignant-is the fact that sales to first home buyers-to those young people going out to buy their first home-have declined by some 4 per cent. That is a very sad thing because it shows that the real losers in today's national housing crisis are not older people, the people of middle age who bought their houses during the period of the Menzies Government or the Fraser Government: the real losers in Australia are our young people, the people who should be the enthusiasm for the future of this country.

The Government has created a sort of housing apartheid. One section of the community is especially favoured and especially fortunate because it grew up-if you like, matured-in a period when housing was available to ordinary Australians; while another section of the community-young people who left school in the past five or six years, and are now marrying and moving on with their lives-is excluded from home ownership for the foreseeable future. What we have from this Australian Labor Party (ALP), which preaches piously that it believes in equality, is a divided and unfair society. This has happened above all because of the Government's regressive interest rate strategy.

The cost of a mortgage on an average home for an average family since 1983, when this Government came to office, has increased in real terms by $82 a week. In the past 12 months mortgage costs have increased by $50 a month. That is a tragic indictment of the Government's record. It is a strategy which the Government has been forced to adopt because over six years it has abandoned the alternatives that it could have pursued. For six years the Government could have been reforming labour practices and the labour market, but it has done nothing. For six years the Government could have been reforming the taxation system to encourage saving, rather than keeping the current system which encourages consumption. For six years it could have been doing something to reform the arteries of Australia's export industries, the waterfront and shipping, and in particular coastal shipping. For six years it could have been working at building up our national productivity, yet during that period our national productivity has stabilised or declined. The Government has spent six years trying to rerun the housing policies of the long gone and long forgotten Chifley Government.

What the Government has been forced to do, having abandoned all of those alternative strategies, is to try to soak up consumption with high interest rates so that our balance of payments position does not continue to deteriorate. The weight of that burden of economic policy falls on the shoulders of young people who want to purchase that family home. They cannot do it because the Government has adopted one strategy and turned its back on many others. It is interesting to see that in the last few weeks the Government has decided, in a flight of political panic, to search around for excuses. This has increasingly become the government of excuses.

The first excuse that has become increasingly prominent from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and also, I note, from the Premier of Victoria, is that the housing crisis, the interest rate crisis, is, after all, the fault of the greedy banks. This was the old line that the Chifley Government used in the 1940s. Nobody on this side of the House would argue that the banks were always perfect, that banks never made mistakes, but the fact is that if the Government's allegation that the banks were responsible for the high level of home loan interest rates today were true, over the last year home loan interest rates would have increased substantially faster than 90-day bank bill rates. The statistics show that the reverse is true. In July 1988, 90-day rates were, on average, 13.05 per cent. In that same month, home loan interest rates were 13.5 per cent. Yesterday, 90-day rates were 17.2 per cent and home loan interest rates were 16 per cent. The point is that home loan interest rates today are below 90-day bank bill rates, whereas in July last year it was the other way round. How one can argue that the increase in home loan interest rates is the fault of the banks, when it is the 90-day bank bill rates which have led the charge in the interest rate spiral, defies imagination. It is a political gimmick and it is the oldest political stunt in history to blame any institution one can possibly find for the failure of one's own policies.

Nowadays we are getting reports in newspapers-discreetly leaked, no doubt, from the Treasurer's office-that an official in the Treasury has written a letter to the banks asking them to explain why they have not honoured a deal that the Government reached with them in 1986. This letter which we read about in all the newspapers has no doubt been leaked to try to direct more blame for the Government's high interest rate strategy towards the banks.

In 1986 the banks were paid $120m by the Government on two conditions. The first of those conditions was that the banks would lend at least $6 billion in the 1986-87 financial year and thereafter for the purpose of housing. The banks did that; they exceeded that goal, so the first condition was met by the banks. The second condition that the Government laid down was that there should be more flexible lending packages provided by the banks. Once more the banks have provided those more flexible lending packages, such as low-start or fixed interest loans. The fact that people in the community have not rushed to take up these new options is, I guess, a reflection of the natural conservatism of Australians. I do not criticise people for that. It is also true that the banks have met that condition by providing more flexible lending packages. The information that the Treasurer or the Treasury have leaked to the newspapers chooses not to reveal that the six biggest banks in Australia have all replied to that letter from the Treasury and have pointed out that the conditions laid down by the Government in 1986 have been met. So this first excuse that the banks are responsible for the housing chaos which has hit Australia is totally and demonstrably false.

The second excuse is the one from the Treasurer, which I note he has recently started to back away from, that the reason for the housing crisis in Australia is that home owners themselves are irresponsible. Do people remember this famous statement by the Treasurer, `The person in a house, on a block of land, with a backyard swimming pool, a rotary hoist and a front yard, is driving up house prices, not governments'? Apparently, the blame falls on the home owners themselves. That excuse was seen to be politically inconvenient, so it has recently been walked away from. What we found in its place was the third great excuse for the housing crisis-that it was all the fault of the States. The States were responsible because they had pushed up housing prices as they did not have proper land supply policies. Let me tell the House that even in Sydney about 50 per cent of the increase in housing costs for mortgagees over the last six years has been due to interest rates alone, and in other States the percentage due to interest rates alone ranged up to 90 per cent. So that argument is not true and the untruth of it was revealed in a paper published yesterday for the National Housing Review, known as Background Paper No. 2. That paper makes the simple point that a comparison of the ownership rates for income units in 1981-82 and 1985-86 shows that the proportion of owner purchasers has declined at every income level for all family types. it points out that this is as a result of rising interest rates. Again, the excuse that it is all the fault of the States is false. The blame lies once more where it will always lie in the minds of the community-here in Canberra, with the Government's monetary and high interest rates policy.

The excuses of the Government are dishonest and phoney. The public is not accepting them and it never will. The last resort of the Government, as its excuses begin to fall by the wayside, is to cook the books on the consumer price index. When that figure comes out this Thursday, the weight given to housing will have been devalued. We will see a more favourable figure, and a prayer from the Government that home loan interest rates might come down as a result. Of course, people will not be deceived; they will know that the books have been cooked this time.

What conclusion can we draw when we look at the wreckage of the lives of young people which has been caused by this Government? When they left school they hoped they would be able to emulate their parents and buy a home, and have their lives revolve around that home? What conclusion can we draw from six years under Labor? We can draw the quite clear conclusion that it has taken away from a generation of Australians the aspiration of home ownership, which is at the very foundation of Australian society. Let me tell honourable members on the other side of the House that young potential home buyers will strangle the political life out of the Hawke-Keating Government at the next election with all the enthusiasm of a farmer throttling his Christmas turkey.

This will allow works to be referred where, because of their nature, only limited design work can be completed before Committee consideration is necessary. The Committee is satisfied that the changes will facilitate its operations and activities and wishes to record its appreciation to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) for making officers of his Department available to brief it on the proposed changes.

There is one matter on which I wish to comment, one which is of considerable concern to the Committee. I refer to the exemption from the Public Works Committee Act in August 1988 of the following Government business enterprises: Australian Postal Commission; Aussat Pty Ltd; Overseas Telecommunications Commission; and the Australian Telecommunications Commission. DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION (CONVERSION INTO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Moore had moved by way of amendment:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Government should sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to the private sector, with the first option to purchase being given to the Corporation's employees'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two speeches in five minutes must be some sort of record for me. This Bill was debated during the last period of sitting, at which time I was to follow the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). I listened to his speech with great interest and I have had the opportunity to study it again in Hansard. Interestingly, the honourable member for Ryan indicated that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation was one of the companies nominated for privatisation on the Opposition hit list. Naturally, I support the Bill before the House and oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill amends the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970 in such a way as to convert the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, or SMEC as it is commonly known, into a public company called the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Ltd. It will also remove a variety of statutory controls which inhibit SMEC's commercial operations, thereby making it more competitive.

This Bill represents a major step forward in implementing the reform package for the Corporation announced last August by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), and is part of the Hawke Labor Government's comprehensive program to improve the performance of government business enterprises. Without doubt, the Snowy Mountains scheme is the most imaginative and daring project ever initiated by an Australian government. Naturally, it was a Labor government. Full credit for the scheme must go to the Chifley Labor Government and especially to Prime Minister Ben Chifley himself. In a broadcast `Report to the Nation' in May 1949 he declared:

The Snowy Mountains plan is the greatest single plan in our history. It is a plan for the whole nation, belonging to no one State nor to any group or section. It is a two-sided plan because it provides not only for the provision of vast supplies of new power but also for an immense decentralisation of industry and population. This is a plan for the nation and it needs the nation to back it.

History shows that, while the conservative Opposition belatedly came to the position of supporting this great work of engineering and imagination, had it been left to it alone it would never have happened. Yet, several years down the track, at a function at the Tumut Pond dam in 1956, the very same person who had in the first instance condemned the Chifley Government's proposal as the work of socialism showed a complete about-face. At this function the Prime Minister of the day, Sir Robert Gordon Menzies, had this to say:

In a period in which we in Australia are still, I think, handicapped by parochialism, by a slight distrust of big ideas and of big people or of big enterprises . . . this scheme is teaching us and everybody in Australia to think in a big way, to be thankful for big things, to be proud of big enterprises and . . . to be thankful for big men.

It would seem that Prime Minister Menzies was wrong. Despite the great success of the Snowy scheme, despite its obvious lessons, it would seem that our conservative opponents have learned nothing. Would that the conservatives sitting opposite and those in business, especially in our manufacturing industries, would take these words to heart, then Australia might begin to face the challenge of the future.

Should anyone require further proof of what I say, I suggest that person make but a cursory examination of the so-called Future Directions policy statement of the Opposition. It will become immediately obvious to the puzzled reader that its title is a complete misnomer-a more correct title would be `Past Directions'. That is indeed the nature of conservatism: to take us galloping into the past in a vain attempt to avoid the challenges of the future.

While many Australians had discussed the possibility of such a Snowy Mountains scheme off and on for the previous 70 years, had it not been for the energy, vision and drive of the Chifley Labor Government it would have remained a pipe-dream. While the scheme rapidly gained the support of all Australians, it was Prime Minister Chifley and his Labor Government that pushed it ahead in the face of conservative opposition under the leadership of Sir Robert Menzies, who saw it as yet another horrible example of socialism.

Some things do not change. It is of the very essence of conservatism that its adherents are unable to think big and imaginatively. It is of their very nature that conservatives seek to conserve-that is, to cling desperately to tired old ways and refuse to see the need for change. There is no better example of this in Australia's political history than the Snowy Mountains scheme. As the recently deceased and much admired Nelson Lemmon, Minister for Works and Housing in the Chifley Labor Government, said in his second reading speech of 26 May 1949 on the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Power Bill:

The Bill is not a complex one. It is simple and has the clear and definite purpose to set up an authority with adequate powers to construct the largest public works undertaking ever conceived in this country and one that is pregnant with good for the whole community by making available large blocks of electric power for defence in the event of war, and for industrial activities in times of peace, and large quantities of controlled water for irrigation. This is a work that has been talked of for 70 years. This Government has firmly resolved that words shall be transferred to deeds. The Government faces this task of construction in the knowledge that it will encounter many problems. No doubt at times we shall meet with some disappointments and the work will have many critics. However, those critics in the main will be people who have little faith. This Government has faith in its engineers, its people and the future of Australia.

The Snowy Mountains scheme was indeed a magnificent project which relied for its success on the work of many outstanding persons. One of the most remarkable was Sir William Hudson, the first Commissioner of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. The story of his getting the job is as typical of the more informal nature of the 1940s as it is of the manner of operation of the Chifley Government. The then Chairman of the Commonwealth Public Service Board, Mr W. E. Dunk, met Nelson Lemmon and gave him an envelope which had been handed to him at a cricket match. The note suggested that the man for the job was Bill Hudson. Some years later, Lemmon described his subsequent interview with Bill Hudson:

When Hudson walked into my office he was bent on one side and wore a rather crumpled coat. I said: `I don't think you look strong enough for the job.' He said: `I have a sleeping appendix'. I said: `You won't start the Snowy job until you get it out.' The more I talked with him the more impressed I became.

I took him to Chifley. Ben sat back sucking his pipe and said: `Well, Mr Hudson, tell me about yourself.' Hudson looked embarrassed and said: `I don't like talking about myself.' Ben (Chifley) said: `That's a pretty fair sort of an answer.' He already knew quite a lot. I told Hudson afterwards that the Prime Minister would back him in Cabinet. Hudson got his appendix out two days later.
He then got the job.

In 1953 it was estimated that the scheme would cost the equivalent of $800m. It is largely due to Sir William Hudson that it was completed within that limit of expenditure, something which causes me, as Chairman of this Parliament's Public Works Committee, both amazement and delight. The Snowy Mountains scheme relied for its success on many other wonderful persons who worked hard in difficult and dangerous conditions and who, despite this, for years afterwards were objects of derision by other Australians who had been here but a few decades more than they had. Many of these people now live in my electorate of Throsby. I refer, of course, to the many good people and excellent workers who migrated to Australia in the late 1940s and the 1950s. These unsung heroes, who comprised more than two-thirds of the total work force of the Snowy Mountains Authority, have done so much to make Australia the great place it is today. That is something that the conservatives sitting opposite might care to ponder as they seek to stop other people migrating to Australia today.

Much has happened in the intervening years since the scheme was completed. In 1970 the Authority was formed into a corporation specialising in consultancy work based on its vast experience and expertise built up over those years. The corporation was established under the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act to preserve and capitalise on the professional engineering expertise developed during the construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme and to expand on the aid-related activities of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. A large number of skilled staff had been recruited overseas to construct the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme, but there was a desire to retain their skills in Australia. By creating a statutory authority, the Government hoped to retain these skills and thereby enhance foreign policy objectives, reduce the need to use foreign consultants and provide a means of opening overseas markets to Australian consultants, as well as to provide a source of export income.

In addition to delivering a reasonable return on its capital, SMEC was also required to meet Government expectations in the areas I have just listed. There were a number of constraints on SMEC's activities that were designed to facilitate this. Both its clients and its field of work were limited by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970. Further, ministerial approval was required for any project which SMEC was to undertake. Nevertheless, it had no problem in delivering a return on its capital and, until 1983, returned a profit and delivered a dividend to the Government totalling $3.3m. Since 1970 SMEC has completed 1,350 projects in 50 countries with a capital value of $4,500m and has earned consulting fees of $294m. It has paid corporate taxes amounting to $11m, as well as $7m in State payroll and land taxes and $1.3m in local government taxes.

The Corporation has worked in a wide range of countries and often in remote and inaccessible areas. To do this requires a very special kind of staff, who are committed to their profession and prepared to endure long periods without access to many of the amenities that most of us regard as necessities. The Corporation is fortunate to have such staff with wives and families who are prepared to support them in such difficult circumstances. The Corporation has proved itself as a winner of export awards and has assisted the development of the Australian engineering consulting industry through joint ventures. It has an excellent overseas track record.

The Corporation has placed increasing emphasis on working in association with other Australian consulting organisations where its partners can bring complementary skills or resources to specific projects in which it is interested. For instance, the Corporation has entered into an agreement with Pak-Poy and Kneebone Pty Ltd to work together on selected projects in Hong Kong, China and Macau. Such associations can add considerable strength to submissions made against international competition and so measurably increase the prospects of their being awarded to that Australian team. The Corporation also places great importance on strengthening its Australian market share to provide a firm base for its overseas endeavours. In 1989 they have participated in the very fast train project in south-east Australia and the major Tully hydropower project in Queensland. The Corporation is obviously entering a new and very exciting phase of its development. With its strengthened financial structure and the quality and competency of its staff, it is now well placed to continue to grow, prosper and provide a major contribution to Australia's international engineering consulting reputation.

Despite its outstanding performance, in 1983 SMEC was faced with a downturn in the worldwide engineering consulting market and for the first time returned a loss. Consultants were called in to determine the cause of its problems and to propose solutions. They made an extremely gloomy assessment. The major cause of the downturn in SMEC's fortunes was identified as its inability to adjust quickly to the changing environment. The majority of the work was overseas on infrastructure projects. As a consequence, SMEC suffered greatly when there was a world wide pattern of reduced emphasis on infrastructure development. Reduced aid flows from the oil exporting countries and debt problems of many developing countries led to reductions in overseas development programs. This reduced emphasis led to greater competition amongst existing consulting firms, both Australian and overseas-based companies, resulting in smaller profits on new work for SMEC and a reduced rate of success in bidding.

Because of the constraints on SMEC's development and the commercial practices that the organisation had developed, SMEC was ill-suited to meet market fluctuations. Changes were obviously needed in a number of areas. The Bill now before the House seeks to address these problem areas. In summary, this Bill provides for the conversion of SMEC into a public company under the Companies Act; maintains the corporate identity of SMEC so that all existing contracts, its taxation position and other assets and liabilities are unchanged upon conversion; provides for all staff to continue in employment on their present terms and conditions and preserves all their accrued entitlements; removes the day to day bureaucratic controls over the commercial decision making processes of the Corporation and replaces these with the structures of the requirements of the companies legislation and places SMEC on the same footing in this regard as any other public company. The head office of SMEC will remain based in Cooma and the new company will continue to contribute benefits to the Cooma area.

The Snowy Mountains scheme has been one of the great success stories of Australia. With the restructuring of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, I have every reason to believe that it will continue to be an ongoing success story, thanks in no small part to the vision and sound economic management of the Hawke Labor Government as it builds on the achievements of the Chifley Labor Government of some 40 years ago. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), some people might become confused as to the exact nature of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill being discussed in the House. Certainly, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) owed its genesis to the magnificent Snowy Mountains scheme but, as the honourable member for Throsby ultimately admitted, it is now a totally separate organisation called SMEC. Theoretically and in law, it has nothing to do with the Snowy Mountains Authority (SMA) today. It has its headquarters in Cooma, but it has had separate enabling legislation since 1970 when the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act came into being and set up SMEC to carry on its essentially engineering consultancy work both within Australia and overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the honourable member for Throsby at one stage referred to the inability `to see the need for change'. He was not referring specifically to the Opposition, but I point out to the House at the outset that the Opposition feels very strongly indeed that there is a need to change even further the role, construction and operation of SMEC by providing for it to be privatised in an effective manner and by giving the first option to purchase to the Corporation's employees. We would then see SMEC take off in a constructive way and really perform in the interests of its shareholders and Australia. In that context I support fully the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), which lies on the table of this House.

This legislation, by its very nature, certainly impacts on the entirety of SMEC as it exists today. I am delighted that the electorate of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) and my electorate have benefited from some of the work carried out by these engineers. This legislation ranges right across the entity-the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. It is instructive to look at the eighteenth annual report of SMEC and see just how wide-ranging its activities are both in Australia and beyond. It has a number of sensible projects State by State in Australia. As we consider this legislation I highlight one in particular. It is an assignment officially listed for 1987-88 and refers to the work of SMEC in relation to the proposal for a very fast train (VFT) service between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne.

The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation assisted with detailed investigations and pre-feasibility level alignment studies for the 800-kilometre section between Campbelltown, Goulburn, Canberra, Cooma and Bairnsdale and Dandenong in Victoria as one of the options associated with the very fast train concept. I am just sorry that in that round of studies at that time the Sydney, Goulburn, Northbourne Avenue interchange in the northern part of Canberra, south Yass, east Wagga, Henty, west Albury, Wanga- ratta, Benalla, Melbourne route was not considered. That was the so-called western or inland option. That western or inland option is shorter than the Gippsland option, is on more level terrain than the Gippsland option, involves no tunnelling with compromise to curves and grades for the VFT track and, finally, does not in any way impinge on any national parks. I know that you, Madam Deputy Speaker, will hold this dear to your heart when you view the very fast train, which might ultimately be extended from Sydney to Brisbane. But that is clearly further down the track.

As we consider the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Bill and the range of activities undertaken by SMEC, I have to praise the standard of its work carried out both in Australia, where it has competitively and successfully tendered against other engineering consultants, and overseas. In terms of overseas projects, it is instructive to see that some 23 countries were involved in assignments in 1987-88. Six of those countries are outside the Asian region in the broadest interpretation. They are Botswana, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Somalia, Egypt and Iran. I am delighted to see that the other 17 countries are closer to home and that the projects are of direct benefit in terms of Australia's aid program. This will ensure that some of our aid dollars will help create jobs not only in the countries we are helping but also in Australia. That is one matter people overlook when they come out with strong attacks of our foreign aid program. It is not a one way street. Australia gave $5m aid to a lignite project in Thailand just near Chiang Mai. Some $30m of export income for Australia was generated as a direct consequence of that original or seeding $5m aid grant. One should not be blinkered about the role of foreign aid. It does need to be tightened up. But that is not the main subject of this debate.

Nevertheless, I highlight to the House that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation is continuing to carry out work in countries such as Sri Lanka, India, Bhutan, Nepal, Bangladesh, Burma, China, Laos, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Kiribati, Western Samoa, Fiji and Vanuatu. I have had the privilege, to some extent at my own expense, of looking at a number of those projects being carried out by SMEC officers either as mainstream consultants involved with the project or merely as consultants on a subcontracted basis. For example, there is the huge project in Nepal known as the Marsyangdi hydro-electric scheme, just to the west of Kathmandu. I remember the day well because the Royal Nepalese Army sent me a bill for half the helicopter cost associated with travelling from Kathmandu to Marsyangdi, where I met with the Australians working for SMEC on that project.

I highlight that project for two reasons. It was a battle for SMEC, which injected enormous costs and activity into trying to win through the competitive tendering process to become the major project manager and operator of that vital hydro-electric scheme in the developing country of Nepal. It is a sad truism that not necessarily the best or the cheapest tender will win in every circumstance, including in a country such as Nepal. SMEC must wage battles overseas that are many and varied to win this work essentially for Australian consultants. But when it is won, the performance and high standards that are brought forward are acknowledged by many. It is seen first hand by visiting so many of its projects.

It is a matter of great regret that there are Australian citizens in Nepal suffering very severe hardship at the moment, as are Nepalese, because of India's decision to close almost all of the trading posts and land access to this tiny land-locked country between India and Tibet. Again, this is not mainstream to this debate before the House, but it is a matter of very real concern. It is a very sensitive matter to the two countries concerned, namely, India and Nepal; on the one hand, huge India, which has the fourth largest army in the world, and, on the other hand, tiny land-locked Nepal, which has a delicate and emerging economy. The Australian Government needs to monitor very closely developments in that dispute because SMEC officers are directly affected by what is going on in that area.

In indicating the depth of work carried out overseas by SMEC I also refer to some other isolated and difficult hardship posts in countries where SMEC operates, in particular Bhutan and Bangladesh. TALK.START.PARA: —I support this legislation that will amend the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970 to convert the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-SMEC-into a public company. SPEECH.PARA: As other members have said, the Corporation was established under the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Act 1970 to preserve the professional engineering expertise developed during the construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme. Its functions now include investigating, advising on, designing, supervising, maintaining and operating engineering works both within Australia and overseas. Since 1970 SMEC has completed 1,350 projects in 50 countries, with a capital value of $4,500m, and has earned consulting fees of $294m. As indicated by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) in his second reading speech, the real assets of the Corporation lie in human capital and its skills base, as a professional organisation marketing its skills in an international area. It has an outstanding international reputation for engineering excellence, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. SMEC was ranked sixty-second in a 1988 world survey of international engineering consulting firms. It is unique in this nation in its contribution to the export of engineering services, both as a winner of export awards and in assisting the development of the Australian engineering consulting industry through joint ventures and in gaining an overseas track record.

We heard from previous speakers of the involvement of SMEC in the very fast train venture and its involvement in overseas countries. I understand that SMEC is presently involved in over 20 countries, as diverse as those in Africa, Asia and the Middle East. SMEC's head office, as we know, is in Cooma and the new company will continue to contribute benefits to the Cooma region. I recently had an opportunity to visit the head office in Cooma with two of my colleagues, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), after a tour of the Snowy Mountains scheme. One could not help being impressed with the professionalism of this great Australian organisation and the dedication of its staff and management.

It is the nature of this place that we spend a large part of our time debating negatives and the problems with our society and the economy. So opportunities to talk about one of the positives of this great country, the Snowy Mountains scheme, are rare. I am sure that the majority of Australians today have no real appreciation of the nature and extent of the scheme. I would like to broaden this debate somewhat and talk about the scheme.

This scheme is so valuable for the generation of power and the delivery of water for urban and rural use across Australia. Few engineering projects undertaken by man have matched the construction of the Snowy Mountains scheme for sheer size and audacity. It is without doubt Australia's greatest engineering achievement. Work on the major part of the scheme began in 1949 and continued until 1970. A total of $820m was invested in the Snowy Mountains scheme. It was built on time and within budget. About 100,000 men and women are estimated to have worked on that scheme during its 25 years of construction. More than 30 countries were represented in what was probably Australia's greatest ever multicultural work force. Many of those people who worked on the scheme in those days now reside in my electorate of Mallee, and many of them in farming enterprises. During the 25-year construction phase, more than 10 regional townships and over 100 camps were established, and over 1,600 kilometres of roads and tracks were completed.

It is worth reflecting on what this scheme may have cost today to build. We may even ask ourselves whether the activities of some of the minority groups in our community may stop the scheme and even whether there is a will within government today to at least commence construction of that scheme. The scheme took almost 25 years to complete. Its more obvious features are seven power stations, a pumping station and 15 large dams, excluding Blowering. Less obvious are the more than 80 kilometres of aqueducts and 145 kilometres of tunnels, some large enough to take a double-decker bus. The scheme's 15 major dams have a total storage capacity of approximately 7,000 gigalitres. The topography of the Snowy Mountains effectively creates two separate, but interconnected, systems; the Snowy-Murray development, which flows into the Murray River, and the Snowy- Tumut development, which flows inland to the Murrumbidgee. At the heart of the Snowy scheme is Lake Eucumbene, with a capacity nine times the volume of Sydney Harbour. This huge storage collects the waters of the Snowy, Eucumbene, Tumut and Murrumbidgee rivers. These waters, together with those from the Tooma and Geehi rivers, are diverted through trans-mountain tunnels for the generation of hydro-electric power. After release through the power stations, the water flows on to the Murray and Murrumbidgee river systems for irrigation purposes. The whole agricultural wealth of the Murray Valley, and the decentralisation that that brings to this region, are dependent on this scheme. Through regulation of waters in its long term storages, the scheme is designed to provide through a repeat of the then worst recorded drought, which started in 1936, some 85 per cent of the long term average annual flows. An average of 2,360 gigalitres of water is released annually to the two river systems from the storages of the scheme.

The great advantage of hydro-electricity is its almost immediate availability. It takes just a few minutes from start-up for the scheme's power stations to begin contributions to the south-eastern Australian electricity grid. The scheme's seven power stations have a capacity of 3,740 megawatts. This represents 16.7 per cent of total installed capacity for south-eastern Australia. It is this quality of almost instant power which makes the provision of hydro-electricity so appropriate for morning and afternoon peak usage periods and for the daily response to emergencies on this interconnected system.

The cost of the operation and maintenance of the scheme is met by the electricity authorities of New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory. This includes repayment costs associated with the original Federal Government advances of $820m and other later loans raised to make additional capital improvements. It is interesting to note that no charges are made for water released for irrigation. This scheme is an important part of Australia's history and attracts a growing number of tourists each year. During the Australian bicentennial year four power stations and the Jindabyne pumping station were made available to the public for inspection. As well as providing an opportunity to underline the scheme's ongoing role in modern Australia, this move provided a boost for tourism in the Snowy Mountains area.

The success of the Snowy Mountains scheme, the Authority and its engineering arm should be the stimulus for further developments that will increase the security of water and power to the Australian nation. In conclusion, I wish the Corporation well under its new structure, believing that it will ensure that its high level of skill and professionalism will be enhanced and continue to bring benefits to the economy of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak to a particular aspect of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (Conversion into Public Company) Bill, but first it needs to be understood that the Bill provides for the establishment of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation as a company by providing for the existing Corporation to be registered as a company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981. It draws attention to the fact that, generally speaking, corporations which are owned by the Commonwealth are not subject to the provisions of the Audit Act but rather that for companies directly owned by the Government, where the shares are held by the Commonwealth with the Minister being the representative as a shareholder for voting purposes, the normal provisions of the companies legislation apply. That is, the Companies Code sets out requirements for the appointment of auditors and the form and content of reports to shareholders. The Audit Act generally lays down the matters upon which the Auditor-General is expected to audit where the Commonwealth has an interest.

In the report which I have drawn to your attention, Madam Deputy Speaker, there is a comparison between the requirements of the Audit Act and the companies legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —It is all right. You have referred to the Bill which we are debating. For a moment, I thought you were debating the Audit Amendment Bill.

The implications for the Parliament of the Auditor-General being excluded are stated in the Public Accounts Committee report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) no requirement of the minister to table in Parliament the instrumentality's annual financial statements and the audit report on the financial statement;
(b) if government enterprises are incorporated as exempt proprietary companies there may not be any public disclosure of financial information;
Undoubtedly in this case it would not be an exempt proprietary company-at least on my reading of the Bill. The report further states:
(c) elimination of any vehicle for the auditor to report to Parliament except where the Auditor-General has dual appointment;
We have no indication in this case that he will have such an appointment. The report goes on:

(d) Parliament will no longer receive reports on waste, misappropriation, lax management or inefficiency within government enterprises as a matter of course. Even ministers may not receive such information;
(e) Parliament will be less likely to receive reports on whether Commonwealth bodies have broken their own legislation or other laws;
If honourable members went on to read the report of the Public Accounts Committee they would see that two more implications are mentioned. I quote:

(f) the Auditor-General bids for a financial statement audit of a government company knowing that he must formally request on the accounts and records audit as well. This extra reporting requirement is not borne by the private sector competitors. Therefore, the Auditor-General bids knowing that his private sector competitors have an instant commercial advantage. . .

The point here is that if the Auditor-General said, `I'll go into the marketplace and bid against other private sector public auditors' he still would have to audit in accordance with his own Act and, therefore, his costs would be considerably higher than those of any private sector competitors. As pointed out earlier, no similar requirements exists in the Companies Code. In other words, even if the Auditor-General's tender were the lowest for an audit contract with a government company, it would be unlikely that he would be awarded the contract. I want to make one other point which was emphasised by the Public Accounts Committee in relation to this question of government corporations not having to use the Auditor-General. It became very clear during the Public Accounts Committee inquiries that some statutory authorities and some public government-owned companies were seeking to have the Auditor-General excluded so that they could obtain the advice of private sector auditors in relation to a range of other activities on which the Auditor-General ordinarily does not advise. If the Auditor-General discovered that a government-owned company was looking to arrange its affairs, presumably in the most efficient way for the operation of the Corporation itself, it could be a case of its taking advantage of arrangements which were perfectly legal but which in the eyes of the public were considered to be suspect. So there is some significance in the fact that this is the first occasion on which the Parliament has considered the establishment of a public company where the role of the Auditor-General has been excluded. It brings an additional aspect to Australia's trade and commerce integrity because it gives the parties which have agreements which require disputants to go to arbitration the opportunity to say, `That facility is also in Australia'.
