SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports both of these amendments which have been carried in the Senate and which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has just told us the Government also supports. There is no real contest between us on these matters. The amendments are twofold. Taking them briefly in the order in which the Attorney-General has taken them, the first relates to the question of State or Territory laws which might touch on international arbitration. The Committee will recall that, when this Bill was before the House of Representatives on 22 November last year, in my remarks I drew attention to a particular clause of the Bill which is now to be removed, that is, clause 29. That clause says:

SPEECH.PARA: This Part-
that is, this part of the Bill-
is not intended to exclude, or limit, the concurrent operation of any law of a State or Territory that, except for unavoidable variations, is in the same terms as the provisions of this Part.
In other words, the clause under discussion, clause 29, sought to involve the operation of both State and Territory laws on arbitration as well as the Commonwealth law which we were then passing.

In my remarks I pointed out that this was a potential problem if the objective was-as, indeed, it was and is-to encourage more international arbitration work to come into Australia. I put the view there that the reason for this problem was that if international entrepreneurs were considering submitting to Australia as the place where their arbitration would take place they may well be deterred by the uncertainty as to what any other State or Territory law on arbitration provided. Not only might they be deterred by that prospect, but they would have no certainty or clarity as to whether any of those State or Territory laws might be amended either after they had submitted to arbitration or perhaps even in the course of the arbitration.

Accordingly, putting all of that together, it was fairly clear that there was some potential for uncertainty and doubt and a possibility that the result of that doubt might be that we would be discouraging international arbitration matters from being submitted to the Australian jurisdiction. If that were the case, it would be very unfortunate because the whole objective of this Bill to implement the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law-UNCITRAL-model law on international arbitration is to attract more arbitration work and the revenue that goes with it to Australia. The Government has accepted the suggestion which I made on that occasion, the suggestion which has been made by Sir Laurence Street, the former Chief Justice of New South Wales, and the suggestion which has been made by other people, the suggestion being that that clause be removed from the Bill. The Government has accepted that amendment made in the Senate. We in the Opposition support that amendment to the Bill. The removal of clause 29 may well contribute to the common objective that we all have, namely, to attract more international arbitration work to Australia.

Turning briefly to the second amendment-the first on the sheet, but the second referred to by the Attorney-General-this will in effect allow foreign lawyers to appear in international arbitration matters conducted within Australia. There has been a concern-again, pointed out by Sir Laurence Street and followed up by Senator Durack and Senator Hill and, indeed, the Australian Democrats in the Senate-that international entrepreneurs who are submitting their dispute to the Australian jurisdiction may well want to bring their own advocates with them, and that if they are not able to do that, once again they may be deterred from submitting to the Australian jurisdiction, the result being an unfortunate one-namely, that we would be discouraging the lucrative international arbitration work that we want to attract to this country.

Accordingly, the suggestion has been made that foreign lawyers-if I could put it that way-or at least legal practitioners admitted outside the Australian jurisdiction, should be allowed to appear in the arbitration proceedings. The suggestion has been made, and it has been embodied in the amendment, that the parties may appear for themselves or they may be represented by another person of the party's choice who may not even be a lawyer. This is what we might call a deregulatory step forward. Often when we talk around this place about deregulation, especially if one is a lawyer, people come back to us and say, `How about a bit of deregulation and flexibility and micro-economic reform or whatever it is called so far as the legal system is concerned?'. For my part I certainly support it.

I venture to say that the outcome will be that the parties will still be represented by lawyers and not by advocates because, contrary to popular belief, lawyers in these matters are much briefer in their submissions. They take a much shorter time to make their submissions. They are usually much clearer and more concise. If I needed any further evidence of this, I need simply say that the Attorney-General's speech and my own speech are only occupying a little over five minutes in this matter whereas, perhaps not in this House but in other places, non-lawyers would be taking much longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know about that.

—We will see from the honourable member who is about to follow me how long he takes. I venture to say that the parties will end up using legal representatives, whether they be foreign or local. The fact is that, whether they do that or not, there is no obstacle in their way to bringing their own representatives with them when they come to Australia to have their arbitration resolved within the Australian jurisdiction. They can use the locals if they want. I suspect that some of them will use the overseas advocates but will have Australian advocates to advise them in running as to what they should do and how they should conduct themselves. Whether that is so or not really does not matter. The simple point is that this other objection has been removed.

SPEECH.PARA: We compliment the Government on accepting the amendment that was made in the Senate. We believe that with respect to both of these amendments we are removing potential obstacles to attracting arbitration work of an international nature to Australia. We complimented the Government on introducing this Bill and we compliment it again. We believe that on the rare occasions when the Government deserves credit it should be given it. We certainly give it that credit on this occasion. Now, that the Bill can become an Act, we hope that we will see the result that we all hope for-that is, that there will be a great upsurge in international arbitration work conducted in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading speech on the International Arbitration Amendment Bill we referred to the reputations of Australian arbitrators and the fact that they had earned the respect of both their colleague arbitrators internationally and some international litigants. It was therefore natural for us to support the Government. As the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) has just said, we did so on that occasion with the Bill as it was originally drafted and continued to support it in the introduction of these amendments. I want to address my remarks to amendment No. 1, as circulated. As I pointed out in the second reading debate, there is a considerable market for international arbitrations. Given our background and the reputation to which I have alluded, there is a great opportunity for those practising in that area not only to improve their own opportunities but also to earn a great deal of foreign exchange. That could reasonably be foreseen to happen. Many international arbitrations now are trotted off to London whereas it seems reasonable and sensible to expect that many of those from our region could be and will be referred to the arbitration process in Australia. The Bill itself facilitates Australia playing a leading role in these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to which I specifically refer seeks to make it clear that lawyers from other jurisdictions may practise and appear before arbitrators in the terms set out in the other provisions of the Bill. It further provides that the parties may represent themselves. It also provides for non-lawyers to be appointed by one of the parties to be an advocate, provided his right to appear before the arbitrators is established once again in accordance with the other provisions of the Bill as it now stands. Just touching on lawyers from other jurisdictions, that means that lawyers practising in another country, or in another State or Territory of Australia, will be able, with the passage of these amendments and the Bill, to appear in an arbitration in a particular State which is not their own, and obviously, if it is in Australia and they are from overseas, in another country. The practitioners from other States are bound by either their legal practitioners' Acts or some variation of them. From going round the States and from the debate in the Senate, it seems that it is not at all clear whether lawyers from other State or Territories in Australia would have been permitted to appear on behalf of one of the parties in an arbitration.

Senator Durack in the Senate brought attention to the paper of Sir Laurence Street, to which the honourable member for Menzies has alluded. That august gentleman recommended an amendment along the lines which are now before us and under discussion. It is curious that the model laws were silent on such matters. That is understandable because I guess those people under the auspices of the United Nations who prepared the model words would not necessarily be familiar with the federal system of Government as it applies in Australia, although one would have thought that federal forms of government were not all that rare around the world and that they may have foreseen that. However, it is strange indeed that they did not make provision for international lawyers to appear in arbitrations in a country not their own.

Senator Tate, who was handling the measure in the Senate, was not apparently even briefed on Sir Laurence's suggestions or recommendations. At one stage in the debate he suggested that we resort to going back to the State Attorneys-General to get their approval, they having been involved in discussions leading up to the preparation of the Bill in the first place. I do not think, given the time that it has taken, that that was a reasonable alternative. Certainly Senators Hill, Durack, Watson and others pointed that out quite clearly to Senator Tate. It is no credit to Senator Tate or to the Government that they were in a position where they had to contemplate going back to the State and Territory Attorneys-General.

As for an individual representing himself or herself in arbitration, it seems to me that it is ordinary good sense to include this proposal, although I share the view of the honourable member for Menzies that that will rarely happen. As a practising arbitrator in commercial disputes I know that it was always the lament of the parties that they had to resort to lawyers and legal representation. This view was more than once expressed to me as the person conducting those arbitrations. The truth is that State arbitrations-in fact, all arbitrations including those under this Bill when it becomes an Act-are subject to Acts of Parliament and those which determined the hearings that I conducted were governed by the law of Western Australia. The reason is not-as the honourable member for Menzies says-that lawyers can be briefer or more concise. I assure him that that is not always the case and he knows it very well. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose the Bounty (Ships) Bill, but during the committee stage it wishes to put forward an amendment which I will discuss later. Shipbuilding may not be Australia's most fundamental industry, but it is an important industry in this country and I think it is regrettable that it is as small as it is. The 1984-85 financial year figures-the most recent available on the industry-show that the value-added figures for that year totalled $350m and that the industry employed 14,500 people.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, since the very well known shipyard at Whyalla in my own State closed some years ago, it has been true that the Australian shipbuilding industry has been unable to build the large trading vessels it once built. Nevertheless, as an industry it is still able to build steel-hulled vessels of up to 10,000 gross construction tonnes, which are vessels of at least some substance. It is also interesting to note when one examines the operation of the industry that it still requires some rationalisation and substantial improvement. When I say rationalisation, I am not saying that I want shipyards to close left, right and centre around Australia; I am saying that the industry needs to improve its level of efficiency. However, it must also be said that there are some very efficient shipbuilders in our country of which we are very proud.

It is interesting to note that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report of 1988 on ships, boats and other vessels made the point that large steel-based shipyards still retain `many of the work structures and practices of traditional large unionised British yards'. Naturally, that is a concern for honourable members on this side of the House because it reflects on the relative efficiency and therefore the longer term potential of this important industry.

The Bounty (Ships) Bill implements a successor to the current bounty scheme for constructional modification of vessels over 150 gross construction tonnes. The new scheme begins on 1 July 1989 and will phase out bounty over six years, so that by 1 July 1995 the industry will operate without bounty assistance at all. In the interim, the scheme will cost $145m over the six-year period, with an initial outlay in 1989-90 of $24m rising to $33m in 1990-91 and declining thereafter. Bounty has been paid to the industry for about 40 years and the current scheme has operated since 1980. Bounty is currently paid at rates of either 15 per cent or 20 per cent, depending on the type of vessel. It is paid for both domestic and export production. To be eligible for bounty, shipbuilders must meet registration criteria as well as what are described as `orderly development' provisions.

The annual cost of the current scheme is about $40m and currently there are about 20 registered shipbuilders compared with more than 30 in 1985. From 1984 to April 1989, 45 shipbuilders received registration and interestingly enough, only 13 firms maintained continual registration during this period. As I have mentioned already, last year the Industries Assistance Commission concluded a report on ships, boats and other vessels. In preparing its report it obviously reviewed the industry with a view to replacing the current bounty scheme which was due to expire. The IAC put forward a large number of recommendations. Included in those recommendations were: the removal of import restrictions; the phasing down of tariffs on boats to 15 per cent by 1992; the continuation of bounty assistance for ship construction and modification for domestic sale; the phasing down from 19 per cent to 15 per cent by 1992 bounty for prescribed vessels and continuing at 15 per cent for other than prescribed vessels, provided the orderly development provisions were terminated, bounty registration criteria were restricted to those necessary for efficient bounty administration and funds for bounty payment were not limited. Those recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission reflected a lot of concern about the operation of the then existing bounty scheme. There were a number of other recommendations by the IAC, such as the continuation of the bounty until 1993, the phasing out of bounty for export sales from 15 per cent and 10 per cent on implementation to zero by July 1991 and the payment of bounty only on completion of vessels.

The Industries Assistance Commission's objective was to make assistance to the industry as uniform as possible. Therefore, it opposed what is sometimes described as selective criteria. That is a sentiment which we on this side of the House very strongly endorse. It said that if those conditions were not met it would recommend a reversion to uniform tariff assistance rather than the bounty scheme, which was quite an interesting recommendation. In coming forward with this legislation, the Government has not fully accepted all the IAC recommendations. The major difference is that the Government proposes to phase out bounty for all eligible construction and modification, whether for the domestic or export markets, over a six-year period. The Government has agreed to remove import restrictions, the orderly development provisions and the overall cap on available funds. But registration criteria have, if anything, become more restrictive. Advances will continue to be made for work in progress.

I mentioned earlier that we would put forward an amendment later. I will not use the time of the House now to discuss that at great length, but I allude to it in the context of a very important part of this legislation, clause 17, which deals with registration criteria. The registration criteria included in this legislation replace the prescribed system by regulation in the previous legislation. There are three new or modified registration criteria in this legislation. It is worth reiterating what these are so that when we come to the committee stage and discuss the Opposition's amendment we will have a clear view-I refer particularly to those who are interested in this debate-about the details of the legislation.

The first of these criteria is that at least 75 per cent of the activities of the applicants for the bounties will be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels which are bountiable. That is one of the provisions with which we have some concern. The second is that the applicant must at all times employ at least 40 persons in ship modifications or construction. That compares with the existing 20-person minimum requirement under the existing regulation. The third of the criteria is that applicants will have to submit a business plan. Currently, that is not necessary. Existing requirements that builders must be financially sound, have access to waterfront premises-I suppose that is fairly logical if one intends to build ships-and employ one apprentice for every eight tradespersons will continue to operate. The Opposition has no problem with that. If registration is rejected or withdrawn, applicants will be able to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Of course, we are happy with that. I also point out that registration is to last for a period of one year.

The proposed phasing-out of the bounty over six years is an acceptable compromise as far as the Opposition is concerned between those people who called for the removal of assistance altogether and those who wanted the continuation of the bounty at its current rates. Most importantly, though, there is a clear termination date so that everybody in the industry will know precisely where they stand once this legislation has passed through the House, particularly if our amendment is accepted. However, the Government has introduced more restrictive eligibility criteria which arguably offset the advantages of removing the orderly development provision. We are told that these requirements are necessary to ensure that only those shipbuilders with a long term commitment to the industry receive bounty. However, some requirements are, frankly, quite arbitrary. For example-and I have mentioned this already-the requirement that 75 per cent of activities must be devoted to bountiable construction and modification is not only entirely arbitrary but could easily be met by rearranging business structures. A company could set up yet another company simply for the purposes of constructing a ship, and that would very easily meet these requirements, regardless of what the company did during the rest of its operations. So the fact that this provision can be circumvented relatively easily undermines that part of the legislation.

It is interesting to note that the Industries Assistance Commission is strongly opposed to these directive criteria. I have mentioned already that it recommended reversion to tariff assistance if the more restrictive requirements were not removed. The Government has discontinued its orderly development requirement, and the Opposition certainly supports that move. But it has strengthened the registration criteria and, as I have mentioned, it has done that by introducing the 75 per cent requirement. The Opposition would not go as far as the Industries Assistance Commission suggests. Instead, during the committee stage, we will move to delete the 75 per cent requirement and make it clear that it is our intention to monitor the effect of the other requirements in this legislation. Let me make it clear that, whilst we would be very optimistic that the Government would recognise the cold, hard logic of our position-and there are few precedents for that over the last six years-the good news is that the Opposition is not, after all, going to oppose the legislation. The general principles are good and the Opposition is basically happy with the Bill's thrust.

Our objective in moving our amendment for the deletion of the 75 per cent requirement is to ensure that the criteria, which are aimed at reducing industry fragmentation, do not result in a net cost by discouraging potentially efficient producers. Of course, as the rate of bounty phases down, the possible costs and benefits of the registration criteria will diminish. Indeed, once it gets to about 10 per cent, I doubt very much whether the 75 per cent requirement will even be relevant. Only exclusive shipbuilders will be interested at that stage. It is clear that the Government expects the shipbuilding industry to stand on its own feet in six years time. That is the basic philosophy of this legislation, which phases out after six years. The Opposition certainly has no quarrel with that.

Let me make a few more points on this theme. To ensure continued growth in the industry with lower assistance, the Opposition believes that the Government must act to improve the general business climate within which that industry has to operate. Prime interest rates at the moment are approaching 19 per cent. That obviously makes it very difficult for shipbuilders to invest in a way they might otherwise do. If the Government did not concentrate its economic strategy almost entirely on forcing up interest rates, it would be easier for shipbuilders to compete for business and to build ships at more competitive rates. The inflation rate at the moment is around 7 1/2 per cent. That is a very high rate of inflation by international standards. Again, that militates against the longer term success of the industry. I also point out that wages growth is running at about 7 per cent.

The absolute level of wages is not the real issue; the real issue is productivity. The nominal unit labour cost performance is the determinant of our international competitiveness. The worrying thing here is that overall our nominal unit labour cost performance is the worst in the industrialised world, that is, amongst Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. That is of enormous concern to members on this side of the House.

We know that to get out of our current balance of payments crisis, which everyone in this Parliament recognises to be the most fundamental objective of economic policy nowadays, and in turn to wind back our extraordinary level of foreign debt, will not be an easy task. There are no quick fix solutions. There are long term solutions which include, above all, increasing the productivity rate of our overall work force. A lot of factors are involved in improving productivity, including that of the shipbuilding industry. Our objective is not to slash people's wages but to increase wages and make sure that those increases flow from successful enterprises, rather than being forced on enterprises in a manner which at times can lead to their failure. If these basic conditions continue, industry, including the shipbuilding industry, in Australia simply will not be prepared to invest for the long term and will not be able to export. Anybody who is objective about the economic climate in Australia cannot conceivably argue with that proposition. The Australian Labor Party might argue with it for party political purposes. It may want to argue that over the last six years it has done a great deal and that it was just bad luck that our level of productivity happened to decline rather than rise in that period, but I think honourable members opposite know in their hearts that the Opposition is right when it talks about the need to do these things.

It is sad that, throughout Australian history, the Labor Party, when in government, has never been able to achieve substantial improvements in productivity. The Labor Party is the political extension of the trade union movement. It is proud of that. That is a legitimate purpose. It should be understood that that is what the Labor Party is. It should not be hidden. It should be understood that that is all the Labor Party is. Consequently, it is institutionally difficult for the Labor Party ever to address these fundamental issues.

Already we have seen the cost to Australia of the Government's strategy and its failure to address these sorts of issues because it is locked into this difficult relationship with the trade union movement. Real exports in the year to the December quarter 1988 actually fell by one per cent. This is at a time when we have a major balance of payments crisis in Australia. In the same period imports increased by more than 20 per cent. I can understand the Government talking about making Australian industry more import competitive and about the need to get Australian industry to export more effectively, but the fact is that after six years the figures I have just mentioned to the House show that the Government is not succeeding in its strategy because it has been sitting on its hands throughout that period.

If Australian industry is expected to become more competitive and to stand on its own feet, the Government must not prevent it from doing so. All government policies must be aimed at making industry more competitive-not less competitive. That is not the record of this Government over the last six years. I will come back to the amendment that we, on this side of the House, would like to move in the committee stage a little later.

In conclusion, I come back to where I began. We recognise this legislation as useful legislation. It is important to make the point that it is quite strongly supported by the industry. It is certainly supported by the Opposition. Should the Government agree to our amendment, we hope that this legislation will have a speedy passage through the House and the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

I think the number of employees who are needed before a business becomes eligible for registration is 40. Further, other provisions ensure that small operators who are really only seeking to obtain temporary benefits without being able to trade effectively in ships are not able to take benefits which are really not intended to go in their direction.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an important proposal and I am glad that it has the support of the Opposition. I know that the management of International Catamarans, in discussions with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), expressed the view that it would not have been able to trade and grow as it has done had this bounty arrangement not been in place. It has expressed its sincere appreciation for the Government's commitment to the shipbuilding industry, and I am very pleased that on this occasion the Opposition shares the general commitment of the Government in this area, notwithstanding that it is a trifle sensitive to other matters being raised in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Bounty (Ships) Bill. I also welcome the Opposition's assurance that it will not oppose this Bill, although I believe it will move some amendments in the committee stage. The Australian shipbuilding industry today is very different from that of the 1960s and 1970s-an era characterised by industrial unrest, high levels of protection and an emphasis on producing large steel vessels for a shrinking world market. Today's industry is vigorous and healthy.

SPEECH.PARA: Our shipbuilders now work in specialised markets where many are building a reputation as world leaders with their innovative approaches to design and production technology. It is a relatively small but soundly based industry which is well placed to provide steady employment based on a vigorous and highly competitive export trade. Due to greater specialisation, many firms do not build the same range of vessels as they did, say, five years ago. Export demand for vessels, particularly fishing vessels, yachts and ferries, has become increasingly important in contributing to a higher level of throughput for Australian shipbuilders. The success of the industry in making steady progress towards becoming a viable export oriented branch of the Australian manufacturing sector has been characterised by a significant increase in total employment, continuing industry rationalisation, remarkable innovations in both materials and product design, increased capital investment and a particularly high level of industrial harmony.

An increasing level of innovation is apparent among many of the leading members of the industry. Some are looking at new ways of constructing superstructures using non-metallic composite materials and others are developing novel hull forms aimed at producing greater stability in passenger-carrying catamarans. The use of computerised design aids and numerically controlled cutting and welding equipment is gaining steady acceptance in the industry and holds out the promise of a more efficient and competitive industry. Our fishing vessel operators have introduced many innovative concepts to simplify handling problems and minimise crew numbers. The close links between operators and builders, and the unique combination of their particular skills, are in fact contributing greatly to the industry's remarkable success in the export trade.

The purpose of the legislation now before the House, the Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989, is to provide bounty assistance to certain Australian shipbuilders from 1 July 1989 up to but not beyond 30 June 1995. The Bill will continue present assistance to the industry but in such a way that it will be gradually phased out and cut out altogether in mid-1995. To be eligible to receive a bounty, a vessel will need to be between 150 and 10,000 gross construction tonnes and be both self-propelled and navigable. Bounty will be paid on the production of ships regardless of whether they are for export or domestic use. To be eligible to receive bounty, shipbuilders must meet clearly defined registration criteria which are so designed as to channel assistance to those shipbuilders which have the potential to be world competitive.

Since 1984 this Government has targeted for assistance those shipbuilders who have clearly demonstrated their long-term commitment to the industry and their ability to be internationally competitive. For this reason, one of the criteria for bounty assistance is that shipbuilding firms must employ no fewer than 40 employees, as there is strong evidence to indicate that smaller firms simply cannot compete internationally.

This legislation is in line with changes in the Hawke Labor Government's policy, as announced in November last year, following consideration of the Industry Assistance Commission (IAC) report Ships, Boats and Other Vessels which was released a few months previously. This report referred to the increasingly healthy state of the Australian shipbuilding industry. The legislation now before the House will provide further stimulus and encouragement to the industry, which by mid-1995 will hopefully be in a position to stand on its own feet without need for further government assistance. Continued assistance over the next few years is considered to be essential so that Australian shipbuilders can continue to build on the significant gains in efficiency and competitiveness they have achieved in recent years.

It is most heartening to know that the Australian shipbuilding industry has become increasingly competitive in recent years and, in particular, has been able to compete most effectively on the international market. These developments are of course the direct result of changes in Australia's shipbuilding policy which were adopted by the Hawke Labor Government in 1984 when it decided to extend bounty payments to include those ships built for export and, at the same time, to tighten registration regulations for bounty purposes. These decisions, I am happy to inform the House, have led to an export orientation on an unprecedented scale with current export orders amounting to some $300m. This significant turnaround in the Australian shipbuilding industry is well illustrated by the fact that more than 50 per cent of the vessels completed in the first half of this year are destined for export, whereas in the entire 1984-85 financial year only one ship was exported. According to the 1987-88 annual report of the Shipbuilding Consultative Group, exports of Australian ships jumped from $30m in 1986-87 to $50m in 1987-88. This represents an increase of 67 per cent.

What is particularly striking in the IAC report, Ships, Boats and other Vessels, is the strong position of new entrants to the Australian shipbuilding industry since the introduction of registration criteria in 1984. More than 40 firms have been registered since 1984, and at any one time there are normally about 20 active shipbuilding firms. Many of today's success stories come from firms that have entered the industry over the past five years. What is immediately obvious from reading the IAC report and the most recent annual and quarterly reports of the Shipbuilding Consultative Group is that success belongs to those firms which are prepared to try new designs, materials and technology. There is a lesson in this for the entire Australian manufacturing industry. It is obvious that the future does not belong to the faint-hearted and those who rely on doing things in the old ways. There is no room for conservatism in the international marketplace.

All the reports to which I have referred clearly demonstrate that the recent success of the Australian shipbuilding industry has been achieved only by its being prepared-with the active support and encouragement of this Government-to invest heavily in marketing, capital equipment, new technology and training. I am also pleased to note that, despite the significant restructuring developments taking place, the industry continues to experience a high degree of industrial harmony with very few disputes or disruptions. The present industrial restructuring is very much in line with the Hawke Labor Government's industrial relations policy-a modern and effective policy for a modern and efficient industry. These developments, which have industry-wide implications, include the agreement at the Australian Marine Engineering Corporation which involves a reduction in the number of unions from 23 to three and the introduction of a clearly defined career path within each classification. Negotiations covering submarine fabrication are currently taking place between the Australian Submarine Corporation Pty Ltd and three production unions for an agreement along similar lines to the other agreement. A further significant development has been the agreement which paves the way for a reduction in the number of unions at the Carrington Slipways.

These agreements, when taken in conjunction with the newly introduced classifications of `ship repair tradesman' and `ship repair assistant', represent some of the most comprehensive exercises to date in award restructuring within the Australian manufacturing sector and effectively put the shipbuilding industry at the forefront of such developments. I am here reminded most forcibly of the pioneering work of the maritime unions which, for some years, have been very actively pursuing the path of award restructuring-

—We know the honourable member would not believe it. He can come with me at any time to any shipbuilding firm to have his eyes opened and his education completed. He needs it very badly. The maritime unions have been pursuing the path of award restructuring, multiskilling, and a reduction in the number of unions covering our shipping industry. As I have mentioned several times in the past-and I repeat it for the agrarian socialist on the other side of the House-the work of these unions has blazed the trail for the Australian union movement. I am most pleased to see other unions taking up the challenge.

SPEECH.PARA: The unjustly maligned Waterside Workers Federation of Australia in recent years has taken a number of successful initiatives in ports around Australia-including Port Kembla-to make the industry more efficient. For example, in seven ports around Australia there are joint venture companies with 50 per cent ownership by the Waterside Workers Federation. These companies are making the industry more competitive and are passing savings on to farmers and other exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable member may say `rubbish', but the evidence is there to prove it. Efforts are also being made, most notably in Fremantle, in the direction of skills enhancement and multiskilling. This is essential. In stark contrast to the situation in other industrialised nations, Australian ports to date have suffered greatly from inadequate levels of skills and training among its waterside workers. As Ivan Deveson, General Manager of Nissan Australia, has recently observed-I ask my colleagues on the other side of the House to listen; I guess that this gentleman does not vote for my Party:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the industry's problems have been caused by poor management, operating in an environment of inadequate competition.

At long last we are looking beyond the myths to the reality of the situation on the Australian waterfront. The path followed by the shipbuilding and maritime unions is obviously the way forward. Just as obviously, the ill-conceived industrial relations policy of the Opposition is the way back to the past. What the Opposition wants is not to promote harmonious industrial relations based on mutual respect, skills enhancement and the opening up of career paths; rather, the destruction of the union movement. It would recklessly destroy the hard-won industrial harmony and understanding built up in recent years, a harmony and understanding firmly based on the conviction that unions, management and government should be equal partners in building an efficient, innovative and internationally competitive Australian industrial and manufacturing base. The Bounty (Ships) Bill now before us is designed to promote just that within the Australian shipbuilding industry, and I have much pleasure in commending the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one goes back to 1983 and recalls the state of the shipbuilding industry and the inadequacies of the previous Government's policy, one will see that in one sense the ships bounty as it then existed was only for domestic purchasing. In other words, ships built for the export market received no bounty, while ships built solely for Australian buyers received a bounty. We saw in the early 1980s the most blatant and destructive action by the then Government in this industry that we had ever seen. The previous Liberal-National Party Government awarded the contract for an oceanographic vessel to North Queensland Engineers and Agents Pty Ltd, when, in fact, the cheapest tenderer was a Newcastle-based shipbuilder, Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd. The confidence of Australian manufacturing industry, and shipbuilders in particular, took a great knock from that decision. Many people in Newcastle will never forget the blatant intrusion and the unfairness of the then Government's decision not to award the contract to the lowest and most competitive tenderer. We hear rhetoric from the other side about competition and fairness, but if one looks at the actions of the previous Government in its seven years in office one will find numerous examples where it did not occur, and shipbuilding was one of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The current Act terminates on 30 June and, without a new Act to replace it, there will be no ships bounty beyond that date. The Bounty (Ships) Bill 1989 provides for a bounty of 15 per cent to apply from 1 July, dropping on 1 July 1991 to 10 per cent, in 1993 to 5 per cent, and phasing out completely in 1995. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) indicated in his second reading speech that over half the vessels built in the first half of this year were for the export market and that current export orders are in the vicinity of $300m. As the previous speaker the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) pointed out, that is a massive improvement on the pre-1984 figure of zero export work. The domestic and export market will be identical except in regard to New Zealand, to which the bounty will not be applicable after June 1990 under the closer economic relations agreement between Australia and New Zealand. In the 1987-88 financial year exports were up by 67 per cent; the number of shipbuilders was reduced from 25 to 22; yet overall employment increased by 7.5 per cent. If one goes back to the 1984 reports, one will find that there were 91 registered yards involved in shipbuilding. So we have seen a restructuring of the industry. There are fewer yards competing successfully in the export market, yet in recent years employment has grown.

Carrington Slipways is Australia's premier shipbuilder. It has been at the forefront of these changes. It was the victim of that blatant decision by the previous Government not to award it the contract to build the vessel that it won fair and square. Carrington Slipways is currently involved in building Australia's most complex vessel, the Antarctic research vessel the Aurora Australis. For the information of the House the launch date of that vessel looks like being 19 August, the completion date being 8 December. It is interesting to note that it is the first double-hulled vessel ever built in the Southern Hemisphere. It involves technology that has normally been restricted to Scandinavia and Germany. If there is a future for Antarctic shipping of any form, whether it be fishing, tourist, or supply vessels, the Australian shipbuilding industry for the first time has the capacity to supply it.

The construction of that vessel has been a fascinating project because it has allowed the development of much more sophistication in the shipbuilding industry. Carrington Slipways has used it as a model to develop a number of fairly significant management packages, including the integrated hull outfitting and painting, the construction work breakdown structure and a highly developed cost schedule and control of information systems. These systems in toto relate to planning, the supply of materials, the manufacturing process itself and costing and scheduling controls. In other words, the overall construction of a vessel, from design through to final launch and completion, is managed and monitored on a day-by-day basis, with management fully in control of what is occurring. That requires much more sophisticated management at both the organisational level and the work force level. Over the years there has been the development, particularly at Carrington Slipways, of a most sophisticated arrangement between the trade unions-the work force-and management.

The implementation and maintenance of the various systems of which I speak require the active support and involvement of the work force. Carrington Slipways has never had more than three unions represented in its plant, which is why it is so well positioned to be the constructor of the current Anzac ship project. Certainly, there were times in 1981, 1982 and 1983 when many people were talking about the death of Australian shipbuilding. Now we are seeing it as an export industry. I am sure that those on the other side of the House now wish they had had such foresight and initiative.

This is part of a package of changes within the ship construction and repair industry. The export bounty was the first extension and the ship repair bounty was the second. We are now seeing the integration of the ship bounty provisions into a single Act, rather than being in a patched-up form as was the case previously. I certainly welcome this. I also appreciate very much the efforts of both the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), and Senator Button, who have both been deeply involved in one of the exciting examples of the micro-economy restructuring process. One can refer to the process in Australia in recent years of redirecting investment into manufacturing, into long-term company equity, via tax imputation, by the use of research and development taxation write-offs to create an environment to change the industrial culture or the manufacturing culture and then, in turn, using a scheme such as a bounty scheme as a top-up.

Fundamentally, there is very little point in governments making up for the inadequacies of Australian manufacturing in the form of bounty unless we are in fact addressing the root cause. The fact is that bounties will never make us competitive. Often they merely induce further lack of competition or lack of refinement. Unless the investment and manufacturing environment is correct, the bounty does nothing to aid the situation. One has seen this in the past in relation to other industries. The fact is that we must make our industries competitive and provide the appropriate environment, where they are research oriented and technologically advanced and competitive. Bounties cannot be used to make up for the backwardness of the fundamental base of an industry.

In conclusion, I want to mention two things that concern me at the moment. First, in terms of a recent contract let by the New South Wales Government for Manly ferries, it might perhaps be a coincidence but the winning contractor was again the Queensland firm that I mentioned earlier in my speech. I would like to be reassured by the New South Wales State Government that every endeavour was made to ensure that no State subsidies were involved in that contract and that there was no hidden support from the Queensland National Party Government. It does concern me that States are competing and distorting conditions in the marketplace in a way that does not promote open and fair competition. I would certainly like to be reassured that the State Government of New South Wales did ensure in its tender evaluation processes that that did not occur in this particular case.

The second matter that I want to refer to concerns the question of the extension of the research and development tax write-off. I believe that it is vital that this scheme be extended beyond 1991 and be then followed by a phase-down. The fact is that our industries are becoming more technologically advanced. They are much more research and development oriented. However, it is a slow process to change the manufacturing culture of a country like Australia, with our history of having been so far behind for so many decades in our use of technology in the workplace. The research and development tax write-off does encourage and induce companies to invest in research and development. In line with the phasing out of bounties in various industries, the phasing out of the research and development tax write-off should be synchronised. It concerns me that if those two things are not done in tune and in concert, there is a danger that the bounty phase-downs as they occur will leave industries inadequately positioned technologically-and that will be because they do not have the continuing assistance of that research and development tax write-off.

I want to pay a personal tribute to both Ministers who have been involved in this matter as it relates to an area that has been so dependent on shipbuilding and the shipping industry, and I refer to the port of Newcastle and the work force of Newcastle. It is with some pride that I can point to this Bill and to the changes that have occurred in shipbuilding over the past six years. It has been a privilege to be a member of a government which has been so creative and productive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 17, page 14, lines 1-3, omit subparagraph (6) (d) (ii).
Clause 17 (6) provides:
The Minister shall not register an applicant for registration unless . . .
(d) the applicant demonstrates, to the satisfaction of the Minister, that during the period to which the application relates . . .
and then three different criteria are given, but the Opposition is happy with only two of those. The Opposition does not agree with the provision in subparagraph (ii):
. . . at least 75 per cent of the applicant's activities will be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels of more than 150 but not more than 10,000 gross construction tons;

The amendment aims to make the legislation a little more economically rational. If the 75 per cent provision-as I shall call it during the debate on the amendment-remains, it will then be a question of the Government and the bureaucrats picking who will be able to build ships more effectively than certain other people. I do not think that that is a matter that either the bureaucracy or the Government is qualified to determine. If my amendment is unsuccessful and the 75 per cent provision remains, the provision can very easily be circumvented. It could be circumvented by a company involved in various other activities, such as ship repair, setting up a company simply for the purposes of constructing a ship, with the company thus established to be 100 per cent involved in shipbuilding, whereas the original parent company would not be. As the legislation stands, I do not think it makes a great deal of sense. I always argue in this chamber that it is important to make sure that the law that we debate and pass through the two Houses of Parliament is rational and makes good sense. Given that this particular provision can be circumvented, I think it runs the risk of leaving us in the position of the law being made an ass, and that is not something that I want to see happen.

Our objective in moving this amendment goes further than that because we want to ensure that the criteria which are aimed at reducing industry fragmentation do not result in a net cost by discouraging potentially efficient producers. What I am going to do a little later is read from a submission from one shipyard which explains how that can happen. I made the point in the second reading debate that as the rate of bounty phases down, as it is intended to in this legislation, the possible costs and benefits of the registration criteria-and this is one of those three criteria-will diminish. I said then that once it gets to 10 per cent I doubt that the 75 per cent requirement will even be relevant because only exclusive shipbuilders with a bounty of 10 per cent or less would be in a position to go ahead with that sort of construction.

Let me say a couple of other things about this amendment. The first is that, for those in the industry who are concerned that moving the amendment may delay the legislation, that is obviously not the Opposition's intention. Indeed, it is a matter for the Government as to whether this amendment would in any way delay the legislation. Let me say for the record that it is not our intention to delay the legislation. There is no reason in the world why simply moving an amendment would delay that legislation. Having said that, I recognise-and recognise well-the representations we on this side of the chamber have received. I do not doubt that the Government will refer to this, so I had better refer to it first myself. I refer particularly to a representation from the Australian Shipbuilders Association-in particular, from Mr Farrell, who is the Chairman of that Association. Mr Farrell saw Senator Chaney about our amendment and I have had a letter from Mr Farrell as well. He has made it clear that his Association voted by a majority against the proposition that we as an opposition were putting forward. I respect the views of the Association, but I still think that our view that this amendment should proceed is the correct view. I think that we would end up with better legislation which allowed the industry itself to work out its future rather than what could broadly be described as bureaucratic machinery setting down criteria for how the industry should work and what sorts of companies should be helped or should not be helped.

I have made a few points about the way this particular provision could be circumvented and I have made the point that it will become redundant, in my view, once the bounty reduces to something like 10 per cent. There is an element of superfluity about the particular provision within the legislation. I also said earlier that I would read from a submission we have received from a very well known and successful shipbuilder-Kailis Australian Shipyards of Western Australia. In its submission in support of our amendment the company states that there are very substantial advantages in what it calls a combined shipyard. Let me quote from that particular submission:
The strategy of combining shipbuilding with substantial ship repair facilities and other marine related activities has significant advantages in the synergy between the two operations. These are:
(i) Vessel Technology

By retaining a significant repair facility a ship-builder has a wide exposure to the latest technology being used in existing fleets and vessels. This is especially important in Australia because as comparatively few new vessels are being constructed for the local market and advances tend to be incorporated in existing vessels.
Let me say that that is a very rational and important view the Government should take account of when considering the amendment we are moving. The submission goes on:
(ii) Technology Transfer

Clients in undeveloped and developing countries increasingly require ongoing repair/refit assistance and look to that assistance as being provided as part of the overall sale package. The retention of a very substantial refit/repair capacity enables a yard to provide this high level support without interfering with its shipbuilding activities.

The third point it makes relates to economic downturn and skills retention. Honourable members can rest assured that, with the present economic policies of the Government, we are heading very fast for a very big economic downturn in Australia. The particular point that is made here is one that needs to be carefully considered in the current climate. The submission continues:
(iii) Economic Downturn-Skills Retention

A substantial ship repair/marine business assists in the retention of staff during gaps in the order book or periods of low activity. This contributes greatly to the job-security of highly trained staff and the training of apprentices. Generally the enterprise is in a better financial position and able to quickly respond to changes in the marketplace.

I think the three points that have been made there by Kailis Shipyards in Western Australia are very strong points. Those are points that have been made in support of the amendment that the Opposition is moving. I hope the Government will take into consideration the arguments that we have made in support of the amendment in the context of positive benefits that would flow from it. I hope it will consider the arguments we have put in the context of the existing provision being perhaps superfluous because it can easily be circumvented and because as the bounty reduces it will become irrelevant in any case. I hope the government will take into consideration the sheer logic of the change we are proposing because the Government's legislation is working towards industry based solutions rather than bureaucratic and government determined solutions to the future of the industry. It is this particular provision which holds up that resolution of the future of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest and concern to the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), as I always do. I think his concern is completely ill-founded. SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides that 75 per cent of activity has to be devoted to the construction or modification of vessels between 150 and 10,000 gross construction tonnes. Of course, I concede that a figure like that is arbitrary. Why 75 per cent rather than 70, 80, 82 1/2 or something like that? What it means is that it has to be substantial. Should we use the words `substantially committed' or something like that? The figure of 75 per cent is just one which seems to suggest a strong commitment, an overwhelming commitment. That is really all that is involved in it.

The honourable member mentioned the case of Kailis Australian Shipyards. There is no doubt that Kailis has produced some very worthwhile ships and has had a good reputation, but the point is that Kailis is not currently active in shipbuilding. Its registration lapsed on 1 January 1989 due to an inability of this yard to remain competitive. The honourable member for Mayo was very candid in pointing out that the view that he put forward was not a view that was accepted by a majority of members of the Australian Shipbuilders Association. The honourable member is absolutely correct.

The honourable member also argued that the 75 per cent criterion was easy to get around by rearranging an applicant's business structure. If a large organisation `playing', as the honourable member might describe it, at shipbuilding restructures so that it becomes fully aware of the true cost of shipbuilding and then says, `All right, we are rearranging our affairs to such an extent that we are getting out of hotels and getting into shipbuilding', that is all right. If that organisation makes a calculated commercial decision and says, `We think this is where the profitability is; we think this is where we have a prospect', then let it do that. That is not the result of a bureaucratic process. It is the result of a calculated decision to say, `Yes, we think we have a chance; it would be even better if we had a degree of government assistance, but we think we have a chance. We are prepared to be serious participants and we are prepared to devote 75 per cent of our efforts to that area'. That seems to be an absolutely rational commercial judgment. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) does not disagree with that, does he? His silence is eloquent.

It is not a matter of walking away from the aims. It is a matter of saying, `Yes, this suits the intention of our corporation as well'. It also has to be said that it was the part-time shipbuilders using transfer pricing internally which almost destroyed the industry during the 1980-84 period before the criteria, which were well thought through, created the present healthy group of manufacturers. Leaving politics aside for a moment-which is very difficult to do-I do not think there would be anybody in the House, whatever corner he or she came from, who would disagree that the shipbuilding industry is in a much healthier state than it was five or 10 years ago.

Finally, regarding the discouraging of potential producers, during the past five years only 13 out of 45 registrants have been continuously registered. That means 32 firms have entered, and in some cases left, the industry. It is not a closed shop; we have new players coming in. Sometimes they find the competition is too hard, so they get out. I think the concentration of effort, the targeting of effort, to the people who are essentially devoted to put at least 75 per cent of their effort in the category referred to in clause 6 (d) (ii) is manifestly justified. Many of today's most successful producers have entered the industry since 1985. Oceanfast, Runmere, Austel Ships, and the Sea Management Corporation have all come in since 1985. All are examples of businesses which have entered since 1985, under both the registration criteria and the orderly development provision. All are full time builders producing for the export market. All the companies I have mentioned would have met and surpassed the 75 per cent rule. All of them are 100 per cent shipbuilders. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish very briefly to pick up a couple of points made by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). I rather enjoy discussing some of these issues with him in the House. It brings a little more relevance to some of the debates than is quite often the case. The Minister made the point at the beginning of his remarks that he wants serious players in the industry. No-one would argue with the proposition. There are other criteria involved for obtaining the bounty relating to, for example, employees and so on which guarantee that that remains the case. But how would the Government ever know who the serious players were? If the Government says it wants particular kinds of people in the industry, how will it know that there are not other people who would have been extremely successful in the industry, but who are excluded because of these criteria? How does it know that it is not excluding from shipbuilding people who may have turned out to be extraordinarily successful and profitable shipbuilders?

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to make relates more specifically to the fact that the Minister never took up the point I made which came from the Kailis submission, unless it was during one of my fleeting moments of lost concentration. I do not think he took up the point about the various advantages that Kailis put forward of having a combined yard. I do think the three specific points that I read from its submission were very important. If the Minister has the time I would appreciate his responding to that. I am convinced by the three points that Kailis put forward. It does not seem to be entirely rational that the Government should be excluding any combined yards simply because 75 per cent of their operation is not exclusively shipbuilding, but 65, 55 or 45 per cent may be. They may have an entirely viable operation producing extremely good ships and, during upturns and downturns of the economy, having the continuity of work through repairs and maintenance of ships which keeps them in business. It seems a bit silly, given that the Government obviously intends to help the shipbuilding industry, not hinder it, that it should have a provision which actually excludes that kind of operation.

Thirdly, the Minister made the point about the circumvention of the legislation. Since the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) was sitting here he took the point that it was unlikely that someone would move from hotels to ships, but if he did that was fair enough provided he just built ships. I am sure I speak for the honourable member for Gippsland when I say that his family would not think of moving from hotels to ships. I do not know why I think that, but I have a feeling that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Think of all the sea coast they own!

—I will try not to speculate on that. `Speculate' is the wrong word to use-I will not consider that. We are not talking about some business that might move from hotels to ships. We are really getting back to the sort of structure I was talking about in the context of the Kailis submission. We are talking about people who may have a combined yard structure and who decide to excise from the corporate structure the part which is involved in the building of ships in order to ensure that they gain access to the bounty. I think that would be a very simple operation. To use the extravagant example of somebody going from hotels to shipbuilding, or from some sort of tourist operation in the north of Queensland showing people around a river or looking at crocodiles to shipbuilding, is not a real world example. A real world example is starting with a combined yard structure, excising a part of that business which is associated specifically with shipbuilding, and then obtaining the bounty. It seems to me that the Minister does not really answer the propositions we have put forward. I think you, Madam Deputy Chairman, would be the first to agree that that is a very good reason for the Government to change its position now and decide to support our amendment.
—The Chair cannot comment!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there are many shipbuilders where the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) comes from.
—There are shipbuilders in my electorate.

—Then the honourable member should visit some of them. If we look at the history of shipbuilding from the wooden vessels of the past when ship repair and shipbuilding were interrelated, we find that the technology was similar, the work force was similar and they tended to work in mixed yards, whether it was in Scandinavia, Europe, America or Australia. I am trying to recall whether at the moment in Australia there is one continuing significant shipbuilder-ship repairer in a mixed yard. I do not believe there is. North Queensland Engineers and Agents Pty Ltd, Australian Shipbuilding Industries, Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd and Williamstown fundamentally are all shipbuilders. One could argue that Cockatoo dockyards does a bit of both occasionally, but only in accordance with government contracts. The reason for this is quite straightforward: nowadays, the technology is very different. In fact, the idea of having mixed yards to pick up what is happening in new fleet work is almost ludicrous. It is an expensive way of doing one's homework.

SPEECH.PARA: What complicates the issue much more seriously is that both works are available for bounty. So, how does one decide the split between the overheads of a company-its land and major equipment which are applicable to shipbuilding bounty-and repair bounty in a mixed yard? It becomes a very difficult matter to unravel. Quite frankly, the costs of maintaining floating or graving docks, which are a fundamental part of ship repair, would become overheads which most shipbuilders would not want to know about. Certainly, the shift in the past few hundred years has been towards separation rather than integration. The work force mix is entirely different. Painters and dockers are not used much in shipbuilding work any more, whereas once they were used all the time. Certainly, they still have a major role in ship repairs, but the technology, the equipment and skills are different, as is the management style, because of the major construction management skills required. One does not require computer aided design or computer assisted management systems for ship repair, although they might be required for modifications.

The fact is that this bounty allows for things such as complete engine replacement. The conversion of gas engines to diesel and vice versa is covered by this Bill. So major ship repair jobs are included in the Bill as ship modifications. When one talks about a mixed yard, the Bill allows that kind of mix, because that in itself is a major engineering work, as is building a ship. There is a lot of commonality; it is chronological. However, one cannot say that ship repair is a natural extension. It may be for timber boats or old, simple steel boats built 20 years ago. The fact is that the world has moved a long way forward. I suggest that the honourable member for Mayo should do a lot more surveying of ship repair and shipbuilding establishments in Australia. He will find that the reason why the shipbuilders associations have carried this resolution is very simple: fundamentally, they are all shipbuilders and do not see themselves as ship repairers. Nowadays, very few shipbuilders deal with that class of vessel.

The honourable member for Mayo should also pay attention to how the bounty is apportioned in regard to management, rent, investments and other necessary requirements, as shipbuilding and ship repair work is being done in the same yard at the same time, with the same work force. If the honourable member thinks that to leave this provision in would be a bureaucratic nightmare, I can assure him that taking it out would create a much more difficult bureaucratic nightmare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), very ingeniously, took the philosophical approach: how does one know whether somebody might be excluded by these terrible criteria?
—You are going to reveal it.

—The honourable member reminds me of a man I once met who said, `I could have played like Heifetz if only I had learnt to play the violin'. In a sense I suppose that is right, but if he has never picked up a violin, if he does not know anything about it and has no involvement in it, it is a rather idle idea. Does one really believe that people who have never had any involvement in this industry put down the Australian Financial Review after breakfast and say, `Shipbuilding-that's the shot, I think I will be in that'? Is the honourable member saying to me, `How do you know that they would not be terrific shipbuilders'?

SPEECH.PARA: The three criteria set out in the proposed section are, firstly, physical access. We say that the assistance is targeted. In a sense, some areas are excluded. I would say that, for practical purposes, Alice Springs and Bendigo are excluded; they are just not in it. There might be somebody in Alice Springs who is potentially a terrific shipbuilder but he will not get a guernsey because he does not have access.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree with that.

—Well, that is a concession. Secondly, there is the question of proportionality of effort. The third criterion relates to size: there must be at least 40 people involved. There are some other qualifications. I concede that, but I say that if one has limited funds for assistance, it must be targeted, and the question of proportionality comes into it.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say, for the benefit of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), that I have received the hot flash that Oceanfast moved from hotels to shipping. The honourable member should get on the phone: this might be a big chance for him. I say to him that he must make an absolute determination to be in it. TALK.START.PARA: —We've tried everything else!

—That is right, it has tried everything else. In Victoria, Jeff Kennett may agree. He would certainly like to see it go out to sea. The other suggestion is to invoke the world of the tooth fairy and Father Christmas. I do not think it is realistic. So, with infinite regret, I reject the amendment.
