SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Patents Amendment Bill was introduced into the House on 3 June 1988. It has since been withdrawn and reintroduced to allow for significant amendment and redrafting in light of industry criticism, some of which, I hasten to add, has still not been met. During the debate I will address the amendments and explore their significance to the industry. As it stands, the Bill has two related objectives. The first is to abolish patent extensions which were obtainable through the judicial process and to retain a fixed 16-year patent term. Secondly, the Bill makes an exception, of sorts, for the pharmaceutical industry in that it introduces new administrative procedures for a four-year patent extension for pharmaceutical products beyond the fixed 16-year period which generally applies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's action in relation to patents was in response to the 1984 report by the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (IPAC) entitled Patents, Innovation and Competition in Australia. The Government's action in relation to the application of patent life to the pharmaceutical industry was in response to a government package for the pharmaceutical products industry announced on 13 September 1987 by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett).

In the case of the abolition of the opportunity for an extension period for patents beyond the 16-year period, the Government had claimed to be seeking to enhance the usefulness of the patent system for Australian industry. It has based its actions on the IPAC report, as mentioned previously. That report was the first review of the Australian patent system from a supposedly economic perspective, acting as it did from an initiative of an earlier coalition government. Indeed, it was the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), then the member for Balaclava, as Minister for Productivity, who ordered the review in 1979. It was the intention of the report to provide recommendations that would adapt the patent system in such a way as to effectively stimulate Australia's technological development. It was hoped that such a review would sponsor greater innovation on the part of Australian industry as well as the conditions in which there would be an enhanced opportunity for exports. How these changes were to arise from the patent system is a complex matter, and there is still a great deal of uncertainty as to whether or in what form a patent system is conducive to indigenous research and development. While the IPAC report represents a commendable effort in relation to the complexity of the area in which it worked, certain broad questions of the applicability of the report to Australian circumstances remain unanswered.

One wonders whether the process of indigenous or domestic innovation is really helped or hindered by the patent system in its current form. Patents are a form of regulated monopoly. The apparent purpose of this monopoly is to encourage invention and innovation by ensuring adequate returns to the designer or manufacturer. Such returns might not be forthcoming if a patented product had been subject to imitation; that is, without patents it is argued that there would not be any incentive to enter into research and strive for innovation. Yet care has to be taken with such a process. While research and innovation undoubtedly benefit the community, the continuation of a monopolous situation could impact negatively upon consumers: a non-competitive environment can result in artificially high prices. It is still necessary to ask whether the patent system, in spite of the changes presented here in this Bill, actually results in any substantial developments in respect of these matters.

I raise this concern because 90 per cent of patents offered in this country are for overseas manufacturers, and 95 per cent of those are for foreign pharmaceutical companies. I do not pretend to know the answer to this problem. But I do think that we are well overdue for a close study of the patent system in order to discover exactly in what way it influences our processes of innovation and research. Certainly, once our manufacturing sector is re-equipped, restructured and more competitive, we might well see it wishing to exploit patents for itself. But I am still concerned as to whether the continuation of the present system is actually an impediment to the creation of a competitive manufacturing sector in the first place, and whether the consumer actually benefits from a system which limits the amount of import competition which can take place.

There is a cause and effect problem here, to which a more aggressive inquiry could well turn its collective mind. The need to ask more penetrating questions on the patent system was suggested by the author of the dissenting report to the IPAC report, upon which the Government has based its recommendations. Professor D. M. Lamberton, who is professor of economic history at the University of Queensland, suggested in his dissenting statement that the net social value of the patent system for Australia is questionable, given the Australian economy exports very little by way of manufactured goods and has few manufacturing oriented innovations for sale. To this end, Professor Lamberton called for a patent term of 10 years, which he believed would free up import competition while being of sufficient duration to offset the concerns of overseas manufacturers. Admittedly difficult though it is to walk a narrow path between international conventions, incentive for innovation and consumer interest, a more questioning approach could have resulted in a more effective policy choice. I say this with the Canadian experience in mind.

Up until 1986, the Canadian Government utilised a system of compulsory licensing. Under this system, unless a patent owner chose to manufacture the product in the country in which it held a patent within a fixed time, it was required to allow a local manufacturer to produce it. While hardly winning friends, the Canadian experience did ensure a high degree of technological transfer. Even though the compulsory licensing system has been dropped and manufactured goods now receive 10 years of protection, manufacturers must still provide for a set amount of research and development in Canada, thereby guaranteeing a base for technological transfer. Whilst I do not call for such a system, I suggest that there are quite possibly more energetic and inventive ways of ensuring that our domestic manufacturing sector derives greater benefits from the patent system than it currently does. For the time being, though, we are left with the more restrictive analysis of the patent system carried out five years ago. The Government has accepted the bulk of the 46 recommendations in principle, though it has chosen to implement only recommendation 11, which says that the procedures for the granting of extensions of the terms of standard patents be eliminated altogether.

This recommendation from the IPAC report is given effect through clause 5 of the current Bill which repeals and substitutes part IX of the Patents Act 1952. This clause will terminate all grants for extensions, excluding pharmaceuticals, beyond the initial 16-year patent grant. It will, therefore, also end the uncertainty which surrounded the patent system previously and gives competitors an opportunity to carry out some strategic planning in respect of entering the market. Yet, as part of a larger package of reforms, the Government has found it fitting to exempt the pharmaceutical industry, at least those pharmaceuticals for human consumption, from these provisions. Pharmaceuticals for human use are singled out in an effort by the Government to compensate the industry for the time eroded from its effective patent life by the regulatory delays. For the most part, these regulatory delays result from the necessity of pharmaceuticals to undergo extensive testing prior to obtaining their initial marketing approval. As compensation for these delays, the Government is implementing, by way of the Bill, new procedures which will enable pharmaceutical companies to apply for a four-year patent extension at the conclusion of their current 16-year patent term.

It is argued that the introduction of such a system is a clear improvement over the current system, which is, by any standards, admittedly unwieldy, in that applications for extensions are granted on the basis of judicial action in which a pharmaceutical company must justify its claim for extension on the basis of lost remuneration. Quite obviously, this is a time consuming and costly procedure, especially as the courts would be adjudicating on an open-ended concept like `sufficient remuneration'. Litigation often involved international accountants and millions of dollars. The Bill will bring an end to the uncertainty over patent life which so troubled competitors as well as providing some much needed administrative streamlining for the pharmaceutical industry.

While not objecting to the intent of the exercise, I wonder why other areas of manufacturing do not enjoy the same treatment though they too suffer from erosion of their effective patent life owing to regulatory delays. Telecommunications equipment is a pertinent example. It is also a concern that the Government, though it accepted that in principle it should consider agricultural chemicals and veterinary pharmaceuticals in the same manner as pharmaceuticals for human use, has not acted on its intention.

The Bill currently before the House was a long time coming. It made a premature appearance in June 1988. It was then whipped off the agenda owing to the pharmaceutical industry's and the Law Council of Australia's criticisms. It has only recently appeared, though again with many false starts. The redrafted Bill now appears with a supplementary explanatory memorandum and a supplementary list of amendments designed to overcome the deficiencies of the original Bill. I acknowledge to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and to honourable members that the area of patents is an extraordinarily complex and difficult one. Indeed, the Patents Act is comparable to the Income Tax Assessment Act in size and complexity. Nonetheless, I believe that the handling of the Bill before the House warrants the condemnation of the Parliament.

As I say, the Patents Amendment Bill 1988 was originally introduced on 3 June 1988 and was then left on the table to allow consultation with interested parties. The Bill was relisted for debate in the House of Representatives on 2 March. However, the Opposition was not given a copy of the amendments. Subsequent inquiries to the office of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Button, who has principal charge of the legislation, revealed that the Bill had been listed without his approval. Indeed, the amendments had not been approved by the Minister by 2 March this year. It was agreed verbally between the Opposition and the Government that the debate obviously could not proceed on 2 March. However, the Bill was not removed from the legislative program. Senator Chaney, being Senator Button's opposite number, wrote on 22 February to seek clarification of the situation. Regrettably, a verbal response was received from Senator Button's office on 27 February to the effect that the Bill would not proceed until further notice.

The saga continues and the plot thickens. The Bill was relisted for debate on Thursday, 13 April, but no amendments had been received by the Opposition by Thursday, 8 April, which the Government would know is a cut-off date for shadow ministry submissions. Indeed, these amendments were not made available until 11 April. The late availability of the Government's amendments appears to be due to a mix-up between the offices of Senator Button and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. Senator Button's office claimed that the Patents Office had been requested to supply the Opposition with a copy of the amendments as early as 5 April. However, the amendments were delayed by the office of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business until the following week.

It is simply not good enough. Legislation that is difficult and complex in any event is introduced several months later. We are told that it is relisted for debate, but the 20 amendments are not brought forward for the Opposition to consider in time prior to the debate. That is simply no way for the Government to conduct the business of this House. It means that the Opposition and, indeed, the industries affected by this crucial legislation have been on the back foot for some time. The Minister, in his summing up in this debate, must attend to the matters raised by the Opposition as a matter of grave concern.

Let me now return to the redrafted Bill which is before the House for debate this evening. Under the old Bill, the industry found the definition of `pharmaceutical substance' too restrictive. The definition of `pharmaceutical substance' under the original Bill was:

A substance (including a mixture or compound of substances) for therapeutic use the application, or one of the applications, of which involves a chemical interaction, or physico-chemical interaction, with a human physiological system . . .
Clause 3 of the new Bill widens the definitions so that a chemical substance also includes:
. . . action on an infectious agent, or on a toxin or other poison, within a human body.

The effect of the redefinition has been to enable anti-biotics, anti-virals and anti-toxins, whose mode of action is on a poison in the body rather than on the physiology itself, to fall under the provisions of the Bill.

The new Bill also rectifies another deficiency of the earlier draft in relation to the role of the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health in granting extension eligibility certificates. Before an extension is granted a patentee must obtain an eligibility certificate from the Secretary. Fearing that a conflict of interests might arise with the Secretary to a Department who by virtue of his or her position in the health care community might seek to promote cheaper generic drugs, the Bill has tempered the Secretary's role in the extension process. The Secretary's role in the extension process, as defined in amendment No. 1 of the supplementary amendments, is now less interpretative than in the earlier draft and, as such, gives the pharmaceutical industry some ground for greater comfort. Moreover, prior criticism of the discretionary power given to the Minister and/or to the Secretary to oppose applications for extension without having to give adequate grounds for doing so has also been exorcised from the revised Bill currently before the House. I refer honourable members to clause 5 and proposed section 94 in that regard.

Confusion with the wording of the original Bill also arose from its failure to include explicitly both imported and domestically manufactured substances as suitable for obtaining a marketing approval certificate. The new amendments now override that technical implication, to the relief of domestic pharmaceutical manufacturers. The early Bill was also deficient in that it was unclear as to the scope of the patent extension; that is, marketing approvals are very specific and pharmaceutical companies were very concerned that they might not, under the original wording of the Bill, be able to seek an extension of all substances falling under their single patent extension. Supplementary amendments Nos 7 and 8 do limit confusion on this front.

The problem was that in the initial Bill marketing approvals, which are necessary for extension applications, were set in such narrow terms that companies feared that their patent could easily be infringed by a rival company which could seek to market a similar substance with only variations in colour or size of tablet. The amendments to clause 5 and proposed section 91 of the principal Act-I restate, the principal Act-further specify the coverage of the marketing approval so as to decrease the opportunities for infringement.

Yet another alteration to the original Bill concerns the decrease in the application period for an extension. Under the original Bill a period of not less than 21 months was required before the expiry of a patent was required for application for an extension of pharmaceutical patent. After consultation with the Law Council and the industry, which sought a six-month period only, the Government has compromised at a 12-month requirement for notification of an intention to seek application for extension. The Government seems to feel that the administrative streamlining I have described earlier will provide it with the opportunity to cut its response time to applications by 12 months. Relatedly, although the application time is reduced, competing companies still have adequate time to lodge protests against extension applications. Clause 11 (3) and (4) provide for acceptance of protests up to three months after the lodgment of the advertisement in the official journal, and a further three months after that to state grounds for the protest.

Amendments 18 and 19, which apply to clause 5-section 96 of the Act-affect the so-called springboarding arrangements. Under the initial Bill it was feared by the industry that rival companies might be in a position to infringe against the patentee over the course of the last two years of a four-year extension. The Bill does give permission for a rival company, which might be seeking to produce a generic drug, to exploit the fixed extension period by undertaking certain activities in the last two years of the patent extension period so that they can enter the market as soon as the patent extension period ends. The current supplementary amendments ensure that these activities do not amount to compromising the patentee. No clearly commercial activities approaching marketing or distribution are permitted.

The central problems with the Bill relate to the transitional arrangements, and it is here that I wish to foreshadow amendments to be moved by the Opposition in the Senate. The amendments will be designed to counter continuing community concerns in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why aren't you going to move them here?

—Of most concern is the opportunity the Bill provides for abuse of the transitional arrangements. Non-pharmaceutical patentees have forfeited their right to apply for extension under the old provisions unless proceedings were pending on 3 June 1988, or unless proceedings commenced after this date are finalised before the Bill is proclaimed. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business asked why we are not moving these amendments here in the House of Representatives. I point out that if the Minister had got his act together from the very start, we might have had the time to consider some of the immense complexities and the varied issues that arise out of them. The simple fact is that we have enormous concerns with the transitional arrangements, as has the whole industry. However, the Minister simply has not allowed us the time to draft amendments in a form that will satisfy the concerns of many of the people affected. The Minister has shot himself in the foot by asking why these amendments are not before this House. The amendments are not before this House because, although this legislation has been listed for debate since 2 March, up until 13 April the Minister's office was not releasing the amendments to the Opposition. So it is absolutely disgraceful and arrant nonsense for the Minister to suggest that the Opposition could be in a position to produce such amendments in this chamber. By the time the legislation appears before the Senate we most certainly will be able to put before the Government amendments which will improve the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt the Government believes that the existing cut-off date-the date of the Bill's introduction being 3 June 1988-is justifiable, given that it had signalled its intention to accept the Industrial Property Advisory Committee recommendations. Perhaps it also feared a rush of speculative applications had it given notice of a formal deadline. But these are cynical justifications. The cut-off date should be, in all fairness to the industry, the date at which the Bill receives royal assent. This would not lead to a rush of speculative applications as the court proceedings which would still apply would be too costly to carry out for anyone other than a bona fide applicant. In addition, there is also considerable continuing concern that that provision in the Bill which allows for objections to be posted against pharmaceutical patentee applicants whose patent expired two years before 3 June 1988 is open to abuse. The intent behind enabling patentees whose patent expires on the edges of the introduction of the Bill to seek extension is clear enough, but the provision to leave such applicants open to objections is a substantial source of concern to the Opposition.

Under the legislation an interested party can object to a pharmaceutical patentee by using the new extension procedures. That is, there is a potential for vexatious objectors to abuse the procedures in the pursuit of commercial advantage. Under the old system, vexatious objectors were deterred by the costly court proceedings they were required to undertake in order to put their case. Under the new arrangements, the temptation to object is open-ended in that no grounds for objection are spelled out in the Bill and court proceedings are no longer necessary.

The Bill is supported by the Opposition, but we continue to be concerned about the transitional arrangements. Furthermore, we deplore the handling of the Bill. It has left the Opposition and the industry that is affected by the Bill at something of a disadvantage. The Minister needs to explain to the House-better still, justify to the House-the inept handling of this legislation, or so much of the ineptness as occurred within his control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself slightly confused by the date cycles mentioned by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). The honourable member said that the Patents Amendment Bill had been listed for debate since 2 March, and then he referred to a letter dated 27 February. So it seems that the criticism of the legislation not being withdrawn on 2 March was made a week earlier. I find it very hard to understand why Senators Button and Chaney were talking futuristically in that context. However, I believe that the honourable member was quite genuine when he said that he does not quite know the answer. It is a complex problem, a difficult issue, and the honourable member is not quite sure of the answer-or of his amendments, mind you. At least the Government is getting on with trying to take some action and do something about the complexities in our patent system.

SPEECH.PARA: Back in 1986-87, a number of Government members, in liaison with Ministers and industry, also attempted to understand this issue better. We were confronted with a variety of propositions and proposals which included cross-licensing and a shortening of the patent process. These were amongst the various views put forward. The final decision taken by the Government was announced in September 1987 and I do not doubt that it had the support of the vast majority-in fact virtually unanimous support-of Government members. Some action was needed because the previous extension provisions were complex, slow and expensive. They were also uncertain and allowed patentees and others, through the use of the protracted legal process, to effectively extend patent life without actually doing so. Extensions were granted for up to five or 10 years, which in fact made them the longest patents available anywhere in the world. At the same time, we were looking at an environment in Australia and overseas where our balance of trade was obviously unhealthy-and that is still the case. In respect of Australian research, we saw our best research being applied overseas, and there are some wonderful examples of that in the pharmaceutical industry, particularly in recent years.

We saw the overseas experience in the United States of America where generic products were taking up more than 50 per cent of the new prescription market, and in the United Kingdom it was 30 per cent. However, in Australia it was less than 5 per cent. I hear pharmacists and industry saying, `But you have the lowest priced pharmaceuticals in the world'. That is correct, but for brand names only. In other words, a brand name available in Australia, the US and the UK sells at a lower price in Australia. The fact is that the same product or medication is available in the USA as a generic product at a vastly lower price again. So, in fact, the idea of us having the world's lowest priced pharmaceuticals applies only because we have a virtually zero generic market. So we are talking solely about trade names and patented products, whereas the other Western economies have a much higher volume of generic products. In the USA and the UK the major companies that have patents also market their own trade brands or their own generic brands as well. In other words, the idea that manufacturers of generic products are somehow second-class companies or have second-class facilities is blatantly false, because the major drug companies do in fact supply the generic market in the same way as the major food companies in Australia supply the generic food market. All the other generic markets tend to be supplied by the major manufacturers. There is no worldwide first-and second-class manufacturing system. The generic and trade brand markets tend to be supplied significantly by the same manufacturers.

Also introduced at that stage in Australia was the 150 per cent tax write-off for research and development. This meant that for the first time there was a potential bias towards research and development at the application level-not at the theoretical level-within the production environment. We had also just been through a fairly major overhaul of the drug evaluation procedures. If one looked at the Australian pharmaceutical industry and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, one saw that the drug evaluation procedures needed some reformation. It was in that context that the Government's policy of industry generation, when applied to pharmaceuticals, brought forward three fundamental issues. We lacked a generic product in the Australian system. The overseas companies that basically hold the patents were not prepared to supply the generic product to Australia: they were prepared to supply only their brand name product, long after the patents had expired. In effect, the three-pronged approach was this: the extension of patent life; the introduction of generics into the pharmaceutical system, or perhaps the extension of generics to a more normal level in Western terms; and a higher price for Australian products.

The synchronisation of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and industry policy is a difficult, complex process-perhaps almost as complex as patents. Perhaps that is why the shadow Minister is having such difficulty. I believe the joint announcement by Senator Button and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in September 1987 marked a great milestone in Australian industry terms. Historically we as a country had attempted to suppress the price of the pharmaceutical system through our dominance in the marketplace, and at the same time wondered why we had no creative research application and why we were not producing pharmaceuticals. Quite clearly, the two objectives were in total conflict. What was achieved by those two Ministers was a common policy across both services to allow prices to increase to accommodate and take account of the Australian research that would be involved and the higher costs of production in the shorter term. At the same time we sought from the suppliers a lower price for out-of-patent products. That policy has now been applied and we are seeing the results. Perhaps the confusion voiced by the Opposition has to some degree been echoed by pharmacists in recent months. When we ask them about the implications of some of these issues, we hear similar things to what we heard tonight from the honourable member for Gippsland.

Twenty-five manufacturers are now supplying their products at generic prices. Nine companies have withdrawn in regard to 12 products, and they have now asked if they can reconsider their decision. Those products are now being supplied by bio-equivalent tested drugs which are now in use. It is worth pointing out that whilst the same drugs were not available as generic drugs on the Australian prescription market, they have been in use by Australian hospitals for many years. So patients in hospitals were kept on the same medication but a generic drug from a different supplier was used, rather than a trade brand. It was almost certainly a different colour and possibly a different shape and size, but the therapeutic effect was identical. We have heard no complaints from hospitals, patients or patients' doctors in recent years as to the lack of effectiveness of the Australian generic supply.

We also saw an announcement in February by the Ministers involved, Senator Button and the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), regarding Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd winning approval for the first time for a higher price for its products in the Australian market. That agreement will mean more than $70m to Glaxo over that five-year period. In other words, the Government is saying that if we want to develop good products in Australia, we must put our money where our mouths are by recognising the costs involved. If we are going to feed off other countries' research and development, we expect to feed off it cheaper. That has been the attitude and the position of previous governments. We are saying that while that attitude may have been cheap on the surface, it has been expensive in the expatriation of Australian research and personnel and the addiction of our economy to an import requirement. The fact is that this country does have a capacity in the pharmaceutical field. Perhaps it is not huge; after all, we are only a modest nation, but we do have a capacity. Much of our present research, not just in pharmaceuticals but in associated fields, is exciting. There is a potential not only for import competition but also for export.

Like most honourable members, I support the comment by the honourable member for Gippsland that this is a complex issue. It is certainly not easy for a government to tackle patents legislation without recognising that it is walking into difficult territory. When this legislation was introduced last year many concerns were brought forward. The Government has been sufficiently mature and responsible to recognise that and to respond to it. This Government has certainly been marked during its six years by its preparedness to listen to industry, to commentators and to those who perhaps have specialised knowledge. We are not afraid of amending legislation if shortcomings are brought for-ward within the appropriate time. But the diatribe we heard earlier, in terms of some aspects of the Bill, certainly strays far from the truth.

This is a complex issue. I believe the Bill before the House will be effective, particularly in the generation of Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing. It recognises that we have research skills. We need the application environment. We will never develop any pharmaceutical industry while we expect to pay the world's cheapest price for brand or patented products. We expect to pay the worlds's cheapest price for generic products, but as long as we pay the world's cheapest price for patented products, not too many patents will be manufactured in Australia. The idea of compulsory licensing raised by the honourable member for Gippsland falls down because of its compulsory nature. The fact is that unless the prices we are prepared to pay take into account the costs involved in developing and manufacturing a new pharmaceutical products or delivery system, such a system will not happen in Australia; rather it will happen in a marketplace where costs can be recouped. On the one hand we are prepared to pay the higher prices, but on the other hand we expect that when a product has a patent life and the recouping of research costs has finished to all intents and purposes, its price should be significantly reduced. If the patentee does not wish to do so, others should. The best of both worlds are achieved by the two-year springboard process to allow alternative manufacturers access to the patent in those last two years. In other words, the normal one to two-year delay at patent expiration is covered by springboarding. I have no doubt that the vast majority of the people we spoke to in 1986-87 in the industry and in research supported what finally came forward.

I would like to make two pleas. I plead first with the pharmacists of Australia to support Australian jobs in the pharmaceutical industry and to support Australian manufacturing and research by recognising what the Government is attempting to achieve, and is achieving, through this package of measures of which the Patents Amendment Bill is one part. The second plea I make is the one I made earlier this evening, which is to the Government, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Cabinet in terms of the extension of the research and development tax write-off. It must be extended beyond 1991 for these processes to be fully effective. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Patents Amendment Bill raises some very serious questions about the value and integrity of government granted patents which could have detrimental effects on Australian research and the development of that research by a particular industry. This legislation will deal only with patents relating to pharmaceuticals. Because of the need for Department of Community Services and Health approval and the use of that Department's expertise to investigate patent applications for pharmaceuticals, the mechanisms for dealing with the patents in this industry are the subject of separate legislation. As a general proposition, intellectual property rights involve one of the most difficult areas of law. It is, therefore, all the more a responsibility of government when legislating to consider these matters with the utmost care and to conduct detailed discussions with interested parties before making changes which might affect the property rights of some of the most productive and innovative people in the country. The Government has failed in that obligation with this legislation. It has exacerbated that failure by introducing, without notice as it were, 20 amendments, many of which go to the heart of the already complex legislation. By that means the Opposition is denied the opportunity to fully debate these measures and to consider the amendments to the amending legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation seriously undermines the prior rights of holders of patents by removing rights to extension of a patent granted when a patent was taken out. Its effects are retrospective in that context. The Patents Amendment Bill represents yet another example of the Labor Government seeking to have proposed legislation take effect before it has been considered by Parliament. Labor, under the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), shows complete disregard for parliamentary democracy when it effectively legislates by press release or public announcement prior to the decisions of our legislature, this Parliament. Patents are designed to recognise the rights of the creators of new ideas to the results of their thoughts. Inevitably, any patent legislation represents a compromise between just compensation for those creative efforts and the desire for people and businesses to make use of the knowledge and ideas of others. Traditionally, patents have been granted for a certain period to allow the originator of an idea to gain a return for his or her efforts through the sale of his or her rights or through direct production of the product patented. Such rights should be as inviolate as any rights to property once they have been clearly defined.

If government were to arbitrarily alter people's rights attaching to the ownership of real property previously acquired, such as land, to reduce the rights in the future, those owners of land would be legitimately outraged. Rights to intellectual property should be treated just as seriously. In this legislation they are not. Presently, people are granted patent rights over 16 years with an entitlement to a possible extension of that term if the circumstances of taking advantage of those rights warrant such an extension. It is those rights to an extension that were a part of the original grant of letters of patent and which this legislation will remove or alter to the detriment of some owners of patent rights over pharmaceutical products.

I doubt that the Government is doing this with any malice. However, it illustrates a complete disregard for the legitimate claims of patent holders in the light of the Government's designs for patent reform. Reforms might be perfectly reasonable if established in a manner which recognises the pre-existing rights of some people. However, the brushing aside of those rights throws into doubt the entire package of changes. If we can dispose of that basic entitlement by legislating retrospectively, the entire legislation must come under suspicion. The transition from old to new procedures creates problems in a lot of legislation, but this is no excuse for the unholy haste with which the Government wants to see its model imposed on patent holders virtually overnight.

These criticisms of the Patents Amendment Bill have been made by the Law Council of Australia, on behalf of practitioners in the intellectual property area, and in defence of important legal principles. The transitionary features in this legislation take account of some of the earlier criticisms of the Law Council, but they ignore its most fundamental criticisms. Let me quote some comments made by the Law Council which the Minister blithely dismisses. The Council states:

There are strong arguments for preservation of the rights of current applicants for patents and patentees. They make their applications under the current Act which provided for extensions. Their side of the bargain was that they would get a sixteen year term and have rights to apply for and obtain an extension through the courts for up to ten years in appropriate circumstances. There is a strong question over the equity and justice of, on the one hand, accepting their publication of their technology and, on the other hand, taking away access to the rights upon which publication of that data was invited. It would therefore be just and equitable to abolish extensions for patents only where the applications for the grant of letter patent are after a certain date following enactment of the legislation.

That puts it in a nutshell, as concisely as could reasonably be expected. In other words, the Government had made an arbitrary decision which ignores and overrides the rights of some. There is no attempt to justify this action in the second reading speech of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones)-and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) knows that only too well-although the Law Council had raised its concerns about this matter well before the legislation came before the House. The only rationale for the changes is a reference to the majority report of the Industrial Property Advisory Committee entitled Patents, Innovation and Competition in Australia. According to the report, which was accepted by the Government:

There was no evidence that the social benefits of the extension procedure outweighed its social costs, particularly those arising from the uncertainty faced by competitors who are unsure when rights in patented inventions will terminate.

Ironically, the major reason the report is concerned at the high social costs of the patent system is that Australia has a heavily protected economy which is highly dependent on foreign investment and imported technologies. That is what the report says. Therefore, the reasoning is that Australia does not benefit much from international patent protection for its few products which are traded internationally. That is strange logic. According to the report, the cost-benefit analysis of the value of patents would have to be changed if Australian industry were more competitive, innovative and likely to secure a large volume of exports. If those things applied, this legislation would not be before us in its present form. The Government has accepted the report and, presumably, it has acted upon it. It should be noted that the judicial procedure for the extension of patent rights recognises those competing interests, referred to in the report, through its adversary procedures which oblige the patent holder to justify any extension, and allow representation for competitors, and allow competitors to mount their arguments in a court.

The Government intends to abolish the right to an extension for the holders of rights of patent. This could affect significantly the returns of the originators of those ideas which are the subject of a patent. However, there is a world of difference between announcing a policy for the future to change the conditions of new grants of patent and the approach of the Government, which simply abolishes those rights for people unfortunate enough not to have exercised such rights already. Pharmaceuticals and some other intellectual products present particular problems-which the Government has acknowledged-because of the long regulatory procedures which reduce the time during which a person or firm can benefit from a patent.

The length of these procedures is in itself a scandal and it has denied Australians access to proven technology for a number of years beyond the time necessary for purely safety and health reasons. The Government is willing to give standard extensions of four years to allow for regulatory delays in benefiting from the patent. Court proceedings for an extension are to be replaced by administrative approval, in the first instance, by the Commissioner of Patents. There is a contradiction between the Minister's professed concern for competition in the production of patented ideas and the new procedures for extension, which do not allow for opposition to extension through judicial procedures.

I remind the House that the benefits conferred on the holders of patents need not be all that great. It is up to the patent holder, and the entrepreneurial ability of those who exploit the patent, to make the most of the protection which a patent can give for a certain time. In the event, most patents do not even last the full seven years open in relation to them. The development of new technology and an inability to get products to the stage of profitable production mean that many patents are not renewed annually.

In return for the disclosure of the idea or design to be patented, the patentee gains the right to take legal action against those who breach the rights of a patentee. The enforcement of patents is a legal question which, as we all know, can involve very difficult problems. It costs the patent holder to protect his or her rights through the courts. This is not a burden on the taxpayer; nor are the existing rights to extension, which this Bill will remove.

A major feature of these changes is that they are retrospective in their effects. The Labor Party-a party beholden to envy about wealth acquired in the past-either has failed to grasp the dangers of retrospectivity or has endorsed retrospective legislation with open arms. Perhaps we might consider the evil of retrospective legislation before demonstrating how that aspect creeps into this legislation. There are a number of principles on which legislation from the Executive arm of government must be based. The display of documents about the Bill of Rights of 1689, presently on show in the public areas of this building, illustrates how some of those limits on the Executive emerged.

The requirement that people should be able to know what the law is, so that they can conduct their affairs within the bounds of the law, has equally ancient origins. Of course, people cannot ensure that they act within the law if the existing law can be changed at whim by actions of a future government to make today's Act illegal and/or bring about loss, damage or penalty. When a retrospective law does not outlaw or prohibit certain conduct but affects it in some other way so as to alter the consequences of people's actions, people will do things which they might not otherwise have done if they had the knowledge of what the law was going to be. They get no chance to modify their behaviour before they find that they are in breach of the law or subject to penalties.

When retrospective law can influence decisions on the market, people lose all incentive to take action which might secure long-term benefit to themselves or the country. Retrospectivity reduces people's horizons to immediate benefits to be enjoyed before governments can take those benefits away. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has wholeheartedly endorsed the use of retrospectivity to protect the public revenue from the consequences of the sloppy laws which this Government has foisted on Australian businesses and on individual taxpayers.

Senator Walsh argues that the threat of retrospective laws will be a disincentive for people to act in ways which may be outlawed in the future. What Senator Walsh does not seem to realise is that such retrospectivity acts as a disincentive for all actions, whether beneficial or not-whether beneficial to this country, to our productivity, to our balance of payments, which, Lord knows, is sick enough, or to the individual himself. One cannot count on the benevolence of government in the future, particularly when the record of this Labor Government is so inconsistent on matters of regulation, investment, taxation and the rights of longstanding professional privilege.

Retrospective law infringes the most basic rights of people against government and stifles any healthy inclination to take risks and to engage in entrepreneurial activities. This legislation does not consciously evoke retrospectivity, but since it deals with rights which take effect over time and changes those rights it will be retrospective, unless it allows all existing rights to be upheld.

The legislation does not respect existing patent rights. It will terminate the right for an extension of a pharmaceutical patent, and that will be from the date when this Bill was introduced into the House. To eliminate that retrospectivity all existing holders of patents granted before this Bill becomes law should have the opportunity to exercise the right to obtain judicially approved extensions which they received with the initial grant of patent.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has dismissed this legitimate procedure in relation to the introduction of the legislation because it would delay the complete implementation of these reforms for as long as 16 years. Senator Button's reformist zeal and impatience will see the rights of, admittedly, a fairly small group of innovators ignored by a procedure which is unnecessary and which might well have unforeseen consequences.

Yet again, we have before us an example of the legislative incompetence of the Hawke-Keating Government, which without any attempt to justify its actions will bulldoze through the House a sloppy Bill which takes the lazy route of retrospectivity-where proper consultation and a bit of thought could have produced a more acceptable procedure. We know what will happen: as sure as night follows day, in three or four weeks time we will have to consider amendments that have come to this House from the Senate. As sure as night follows day, we will have to further consider this legislation-just as was the case with other legislation today. This will also occur with the Government's tax amendment Bill, although Lord knows when that will be introduced. That Bill has been sitting around for five or six months now.

The Government cannot legislate; it gets itself into an unholy mess. Part of the problem involves this technique of legislation by press release, of announcing an intention, and saying that the proposed legislation is to apply from the date of that announcement. However, the Government cannot then get its act together, get the legislation into this place and passed in a timely way. That is why we are getting all these amendments from the Senate, As I have said before, thank God for the Senate. If it were not for the Senate, the legislative mess that we have witnessed tonight would be repeated day after day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been outlined by previous speakers, this Patents Amendment Bill will repeal the present complex judicial procedure for the extension of the normal 16-year term of a patent and replace it with a simpler administrative procedure. The new procedure will enable four-year extension, but only for patents for pharmaceuticals which are for human use and which are subject to the marketing approval of the Department of Community Services and Health.

SPEECH.PARA: The present judicial procedure is available for all patents, whether they relate to pharmaceuticals or other things. An extension of up to five years, or 10 years in exceptional cases, can be granted by a court on the ground that the patentee has been inadequately remunerated by the patent. But this proof through the courts has always been long and complex and, by its long and complex nature, a costly procedure. The court's decision might not be handed down for several years, leaving anyone in a state of uncertainty about the status of the patents.

I join my colleague the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) in speaking particularly to those changes that are being made as a result of this legislation to the use of pharmaceuticals by humans. The honourable member for Newcastle referred to a working group of members of the Government Caucus who, in 1986 and 1987, looked, in particular, into a report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on pharmaceutical products. The interesting thing about the nature of this working group's work was that it saw people from different policy interests from those of Government backbenchers in sitting down and talking matters through with Ministers. Of course, when one looks at the pharmaceuticals industry one must recognise the way in which it has been well and truly controlled by the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). The pharmaceutical benefits scheme is administered by the Department of Community Services and Health, whereas the industry portfolios have direct consideration for industry development.

If we look at the pharmaceutical industry in Australia we will note that it is dominated by overseas companies. Many of the operations that are here might be considered as simply branch office manufacturing operations. It also has to be recognised that Australia has a very high level and a very high quality of research in the pharmaceutical area. It was with those sorts of interests in mind that the Government set about trying to come to grips with the best ways in which, arising from the IAC report, we could best do things that might be of assistance to the industry but, in particular, not damage the interests of the consumers and the public health interests of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

I think that it is important to reflect on what the IAC had to say about the nature of this industry compared to other industries and the way in which it handled its inquiry. The IAC was primarily interested in tariffs and direct financial assistance to industry. It noted that the form of government intervention in the pharmaceutical industry, because of its basis on the consumer and social policy objectives, was quite different from that in other industries. I think that that is even reflected now in this legislation in the way in which we are going to handle patents for pharmaceutical substances. That is important. The IAC report said:
Because Government actions in this industry are primarily motivated by concern for consumers, proposals for change must take account of this continuing concern.
Indeed, the proposals that were announced in September 1987 had that concern as their basis. But it should also be recognised, as outlined in the joint media release of that time, that:

The objective was to create an environment which would encourage a significant increase in research and development performance by the industry together with increased investment, production and export performance, and strengthened employment opportunities.
The media release went on to say that the three most important elements of the strategy were:
to replace the then Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Bureau with an independent Authority;
to require the Authority to take into account the level of an individual company's Australian pharmaceutical activity when setting or making recommendations on prices; and
to provide for extensions to patent life on pharmaceuticals for human use.

Of course, that third point is now being addressed in this legislation. Honourable members should be aware that the Parliament has received the first annual report of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority. That indicates the work the Authority has done in its infancy and the way that it has worked up the requirements it was set in place to look at. We then have to look at the way the Government set out in the pricing arena guidelines which this Authority had to take into account. The major difference between the guidelines that were used by the previous Bureau and those of the new Authority was the so-called factor (f), well known in the pharmaceutical industry. Factor (f) is one of the requirements that the Authority had to take into account when setting prices. It reads:

the level of activity being undertaken by the company in Australia including new investment, production and research and development where the activity is directed towards international competitiveness. . .

That is important because it is characteristic of the way that this Government has set out across a number of industries to try to encourage that international competitiveness, being able to have locally based industries in a position where they are able to compete for export markets or for import replacement markets.

That is a scenario in the background of where we are at present. Some companies have already taken the opportunity that has been presented to them by those pricing guidelines. We should again refer to Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd. Glaxo Australia will receive approximately $74m because of the increased pricing arrangements. It is expected to invest $55m in new production facilities and $33m in research and development. At the end point it is expected to increase its exports to a total of $352m over a five-year period. That is the first but it is not expected to be the last. Merck Sharp and Dohme (Australia) Pty Ltd has indicated that it has an ability to increase its exports from $9m in 1987 to $61m in 1992. Already we can see some movement and some improvement in the performance of some of the major players in the industry.

When we look at the pharmaceutical industry we should perhaps reflect on its importance in the overall nature of things. It is an industry that employs well over 7,000 people. There is a local investment in the order of $800m. Annual value added is in the order of $500m. It is not an industry which is not worthy of consideration and support. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme on some occasions has been seen as perhaps a bit of a bugbear by that industry. The PBS, as it is more commonly known, has been very successful in being able to keep the price of drugs to government to a minimum. When we compare our prices with overseas prices the PBS has been very successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the chemists?

—There has been very much a captive market in that the major player is the government through the pricing arrangements. The honourable member for Gippsland, by way of interjection in his normal display of hobbledehoy type behaviour, asks: `What about the chemists?'. I was going to get to the chemists later, but perhaps we should look at some aspects of the performance of pharmacists in the way that they have used different initiatives that have come about, especially in the generic area, to try to get consumers to come on side with other considerations that are important to them, considerations of remuneration. I want to mention the current generic furore. It is quite unfair that consumers are being subjected to this type of misinformation about what is actually happening in the generic area when the real reason for that is that pharmacists at a different level and in a different arena have some gripes with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the way in which generics are used overseas one really wonders why we are in this present debate. Generic drugs are out of patent drugs but are of similar bio-equivalence. That is important. If we look at the situation overseas we see that in the United Kingdom generics account for some 30 per cent of prescription drugs dispensed. In the United States, where substitution is encouraged and consumer awareness is high, generic drugs account for more than 50 per cent of all new prescriptions dispensed. Yet outside the hospital situation, the generic market in Australia is less than 5 per cent of the total market. It is important to remember that many patients would not perhaps realise that because of the way drugs are tendered for by hospitals, those hospitals are into the generic market. It is important to keep that in perspective when we have these discussions about what information should be given out to different people.

I wish to refer to the document that the Consumer Health Forum of Australia recently released entitled Towards a National Medicinal Drug Policy. It makes interesting reading for anybody who has some interest in pharmaceuticals and prescriptive drugs. In a section about generic prescribing, that document cites work that indicates that studies of antibiotics prescribed in family practices in the United States showed that of the top five antibiotics, 86 per cent were prescribed generically. I cannot understand why in the present debate there are some fear and smear campaigns about generic drugs when the overseas situation indicates that they are widely used. When we are looking at a client base that is open to suggestion, it is important to remember that pharmacists need to be fair. Already the Government has recognised the need to embark upon a consumer education program to ensure that people do not have this misapprehension about the use of generic drugs. We have seen the Opposition's resurrected Waste Watch Committee criticising some of the uses that have been made of different public relations gimmicks that abound in the pharmaceutical industry. Because we, as a government, use them to ensure that our message gets across we are being criticised.

Returning to the legislation before us, I think it is important to recognise the opportunities that are being given to those companies that are holders of the patents, those companies that are now being given the opportunity to use them for an additional four years. This is a compromise; it allows those companies that wish to embark upon generic manufacture to enter that field. They are allowed one year to set themselves up without going into the marketing of the drugs. That again is creating another employment opportunity for people in the industry. It is important that we see this as part of an overall package and that for the sake of discussion we do not just isolate different aspects of it and come up with criticism.

I have noted that both the honourable member for Gippsland and the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) have spoken about the timetable of the legislation and the amendments. I note that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) challenged the honourable member for Gippsland to produce the amendments in this place. The way in which the honourable member for Curtin criticised the Government for not giving enough lead time was a bit unfair, considering that we, in this place, are not presented with the definitive amendments that are to be put forward by the coalition in the Senate. I think that is a very strange aspect of the way in which the Opposition has treated this matter. All the evidence is that because of the length of time that has been allowed the different industry groups have had plenty of time to consult with the Government on this. I think that is important. The time has been used to get complete consultation on the different aspects and fine tuning of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This has been a very interesting debate and I thank honourable members for their contributions. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) called for a new inquiry into the patent system. He questioned whether a patent system was in Australia's interests and suggested that we could learn from Canada. Canada has recently amended its patent law to remove at least some, perhaps many, of the features which seem to attract the honourable member. Moreover, serious international consideration is being given in the current Uruguay Round of multinational trade negotiations to trade related aspects of intellectual property. It is clear that the outcome of the Uruguay Round is likely to be a requirement for stronger patent systems of the 20-year model, rather than the weaker ones that-and I hope I am not misrepresenting the honourable member's views-the honourable member thought might benefit Australia. Perhaps he was suggesting that we should not have a system. If so, this would certainly put Australia in a unique position among developed countries.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that there is a great deal of controversy about the importance of the patent system. There is a wide diversity of opinion. Some say that patents are virtually irrelevant and that it is a technological advantage that confers economic advantage, not the possession of a piece of paper. Some would argue that if Boeing abandoned every patent it holds on a 747 no company would be in a position to create a 747 look-alike. Despite the Chakrabarty case very few developments in biotechnology have been patented. In other words, it is not the possession of a piece of paper that says companies have a right; it is the possession of the individuals and the technological capacity to do it. At the other extreme some authorities see the patent procedures as absolutely critical, central not only to development but also to creativity and invention and that longer terms are essential. The Law Council of Australia wants a 20-year term. This interesting diversity of opinion was actually reflected in a very clear-cut way by the response of the Opposition tonight. I am sorry the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) was not here because his view would have been interesting as well. We had two views put forward. Perhaps if he had been here we would have had three views put.

The honourable member for Gippsland wanted an aggressive inquiry designed to keep out the nasty foreigners from Australian patents. He did not have much thought for Australian exporters who need the patents abroad to assist their marketing position. The honourable member for Curtin wanted everybody's patent rights bolstered indefinitely into the future. No doubt the aggressive inquiry to be led by the Opposition would both diminish and bolster patent rights at the same time. Like the ouroboros its head would end up eating its own tail and it might be very surprised at the taste.

The honourable member for Gippsland invited me to comment on the Government's handling of the Patents Amendment Bill. He gave a string of dates which, as the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) pointed out, seemed to be confused and confusing. There was perhaps more than a touch of clairvoyance, but not as to the Opposition's foreshadowed amendments which we are yet to see. It is correct that this Bill was first introduced on 3 June 1988. It lay on the table, which allowed it to be looked at in a fair and equitable basis by all whose interests could be affected. It was exactly the same procedure that we took with the recent Customs legislation. I think that most people are happy with the outcome, particularly pharmaceutical manufacturers, the patent attorneys, lawyers and other people in the patent system, quite apart from the consumers. But the honourable member for Gippsland wanted to know why it had all taken so long. It certainly took many months before views were finally put forward by all the interest groups. It really was not until December that we had the final considered views. That gave a basis for the development of the amendments which it seems the Opposition supports and which we will deal with in a few minutes. The Opposition wants further amendments and I will return to those in a moment. With respect to the Government's handling of the Bill I wish to say that we have taken account of the representations made, even if we have not accepted them all. There seems to have been some confusion about the release of the new amendments and the associated explanatory memorandum. If the honourable member for Gippsland were to check, he might find that the papers were available from the Bills and Papers Office at least a couple of days before he seemed to have obtained them for his office.

The honourable member for Gippsland questioned the efficiency of the patent system in stimulating innovation. He referred to Professor Don Lamberton's dissenting statement appended to the report of the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (IPAC) which reviewed the Australian patent system. He suggested a 10-year patent without the possibility of extension. I am a great admirer of Don Lamberton. I put him on the committee and I think he is an innovative thinker. He is not the only economist to take that view but, as far as patents are concerned, he is not in the majority, either. Economists have been arguing about the effects of the patent system for at least a century. Lamberton's arguments are not new and neither are those of the honourable member.

In a long report which took two years to produce, Professor Lamberton and his co-authors examined the social costs and benefits of the patent system and concluded that the result was ultimately a matter `for judgment'. The report went on to assert that the costs exceeded the benefits, but other economists have come up with other conclusions. The inconclusive debate among economists is one of the reasons why IPAC's report is very valuable. As I said in my tabling statement when announcing the Government's response to the report-which was quite some time ago-its emphasis is on the possible. The report is constructive rather than revolutionary. Economists and others may continue with inconclusive arguments, but the Government wanted to make constructive changes to improve the system. We thought that the IPAC report was a valuable basis for this. There is no doubt that Australian industry wants a strong patent system.

This Bill relates to only one of IPAC's recommendations. Many of the remainder of the Government's responses to the report will be dealt with in a redrafted Patents Act. The drafting of that legislation has had to take its place in the queue along with other legislation which has a higher priority. The Government wanted to proceed with the patent term issue because of its importance as an element of its policy package to encourage the development of the pharmaceutical products industry in Australia. Several of IPAC's recommendations have already been implemented administratively.

The honourable member also questioned the omission from the scope of the Bill of other products which are subject to marketing regulation, such as telecommunications equipment and agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Pharmaceuticals alone are subject to both Commonwealth regulation of marketing and special pricing arrangements under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

The honourable member for Curtin showed touching concern for people who want to keep using the current judicial extension procedure, at least until some time in the future. He said the absence of this would stifle entrepreneurial activity by patentees. He said that the 3 June 1988 cut-off date for the old procedure was retrospective. This is a puzzling assertion. The Government's response to IPAC's report was announced in November 1986. Our policy on patent term for pharmaceuticals was announced in September 1987. The Bill to implement this policy was introduced in June 1988. That is not what I understand by the term `retrospectivity'. Entrepreneurs who had an eye to the main chance, read the literature or were aware from their own organisations of what was happening, would find it very difficult suddenly to say, `We were walloped on the back of the head. This retrospective legislation came out and we had no idea what was going on'. If entrepreneurs had had any kind of regard for what the Government was doing from November 1986, they would have had a very clear idea of precisely what was happening. That is not anyone's idea of what is meant by retrospectivity. One has to ask what these entrepreneurs were doing between November 1986 and June 1988. What were they doing between September 1987 and June 1988?

It is even more puzzling that the honourable member sees this as government by press release. If I did not like the honourable member for Curtin so much I might say I deeply resent it, but I do not think that I can quite bring myself to say that. I have never been a great advocate of government by press release and I am not very keen on the idea of putting out a press release and then saying, `We are committed; we cannot make ourselves look bad and we have to bring in legislation to fit in with the press release'. The introduction marked the Government's legislative intentions in relation to a policy announced a long time before hand. The opportunity to seek an extension under the present judicial procedures is not a right. The honourable member for Curtin spoke as if patenting is a kind of natural right, like the right to breathe. It is not; it is a very artificial right created by statute. It provides a right whereas, in nature, that right would not occur. It is the same with copyright and other similar matters.

There is no guarantee in the legislation that the opportunity will go on forever-and I do not think that there should be any such guarantee. Anyone who wanted to take advantage of the opportunity, who was really serious about it, could have done so and could have initiated action between November 1986 and June 1988. So the 3 June cut-off date simply rules out speculative applications. However, people with a serious concern about the matter would have done something between 1986 and 1988. To prolong the cut-off into the future would provide a major benefit for lawyers who could argue the pros and cons of the present complex criteria ad nauseam in long court cases, but I do not believe that this would be in the public interest and I do not think it would be in the interests of the industry. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate and wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend to the House the following extract from an informed and intuitive editorial in the Brisbane Sunday Mail on 30 April. I am delighted to see the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) in the House this evening. The editorial is titled `Where are the sentries?' and comments on the parlous state of our Defence Force. In my view, it is an accurate assessment of the present sorry state of affairs. I quote from the article:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, as we keep reminding ourselves, is a fortunate nation indeed. It is a place not only difficult to attack-in the conventional way, through armed incursion or invasion-but an unlikely target in all but the worst circumstances.

That is the conventional wisdom, a wisdom that has been so entrenched in our defence policy for so long that we have come to believe in it as the rock upon which all our defence can be securely mounted: we are a castle, surrounded by a very big moat.

And so we are, within limited parameters. The limits consist of geography (the only constant in the equation, but no less subject to revision through technology or politics); contemporary absence of an enemy power with reason or will to invest time, effort and lives in an Australian adventure; and our own unwillingness to man the parapets.
It is the last of those elements which is the most crucial key. It is also the one on which we are failing dismally.

The brain-and-brawn drain from the Defence Force-all three arms-is substantial and increasing. Servicemen and women, whose position is by no means as privileged as some outsiders believe and as some politicians like to pretend, are leaving in droves.
The Government talks up defence. But it winds it down in budget debate, and now plans to bring the service community further into the web of Mr Keating's expanding tax base.

Labor, in short, is a principal cause behind the absence of sentries on the parapets, Mr Beazley's good offices notwithstanding. We have first-class personnel, keen minds, some good equipment: but, frankly, not enough of all three commodities.
The Navy, despite the submarines and the PR hype, is a coastal patrol and protection force. Where is the striking power? Where is its air defence out of range of land-based fighters?

The Army is making a good fist of its newly-defined role of continental defence, as Exercise Kangaroo 89 should demonstrate in the north in August. But its field force is compromised by the need to man new tasks on the Iran-Iraq border and in Namibia.

The Air Force has powerful weapons in the Orion squadrons, the F-111 squadrons, and the new F/A-18 fighter squadrons. But it is short of pilots, skilled people for whom the civil airlines provide careers with benefits they cannot hope to obtain in the RAAF. Pilots, not planes, are the crucial asset in any air force.

Defence, as a department and as a concept, has been outmanoeuvred by the federal public service, which is more concerned with featherbedding itself and its philosophical allies than with providing Australia with proper protection.

I look forward to positive responses from the two responsible Ministers later this month on the commendably bipartisan recommendations of last year's joint committee report on personnel wastage in the Defence Force. We need more than a Minister who was recently rolled in Cabinet and who is desperately trying to stretch out the lowest allocation of gross domestic product to defence in 40 years. We need more than open skies without adequate surveillance or response. We need more than an increasingly brown water Navy. We need more than a ground force that would have difficulty deploying and sustaining more than a battalion group in any realistic contingency situation. A credible defence effort, in particular its personnel ramifications, cannot and must not be pushed into the too hard basket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak tonight on an issue which is very close to my heart. Before I do so, I put it against a background in this session of Parliament where we have had continuous attacks from the Opposition, both in this House and in the other House, on the Aboriginal people of Australia, who are a very proud race. I feel that what we have heard in this House has given the impression to the world at large that something is radically wrong with the Aboriginal people and communities of Australia. I want to set the record straight as much as I can in this small regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to praise the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre and the person responsible for its creation, Carole Johnson. This dance troupe mixes modern styles with a tradition of tribal dance. It had its genesis in 1972 when Carole Johnson, a graduate of New York's famous Juliard School of Music, visited Australia to perform at the Adelaide Arts Festival. Whilst in Australia, she was approached by some Aboriginal dancers asking if she could assist them with their careers. She agreed to conduct some dance workshops in Redfern. The workshops had an immediate impact, because Aboriginals were able to see dance as a vehicle for social comment and as a way of changing social images and attitudes. There is a real need for that in Australia today.

In 1975 she returned to settle in Australia where she helped to found the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre. It was Australia's first Aboriginal dance company. The school was set up in a rundown church hall in Glebe. There were no showers, the dressing room was a renovated closet, and the rehearsal hall was so small that the dancers practised, when weather permitted, in a nearby park. The school trains 35 Aboriginal students at any one time. They come from all parts of the continent and include students from the Torres Strait. In a five-year diploma course, the students cover not only traditional tribal dance but also tap, jazz and afro. They are sent regularly to outback tribal communities to learn Aboriginal dance first-hand and to gain experience of life in remote communities.

The troupe has toured Australia receiving enthusiastic reviews. It has also gained international recognition and has toured successfully in West Germany, Finland, Canada and the United States. These dancers have had a positive role in changing white perceptions of Aboriginals where they have performed. As Carole Johnson states in a recent article in the Christian Science Monitor:

Black Australians get a generally bad press and their culture has never been taught much in schools. But just seeing these young Aboriginals performing at a high standard to world acclaim makes white Australians re-examine their attitudes.

She goes on to say that another result of the troupe is a new form of dance, which is Aboriginal traditional dance and modern techniques. It is an exciting dance form. I urge honourable members on both sides of the House to see this company when they have the opportunity.
