TALK.START.PARA: —I recently had the pleasure of opening the fourth annual Jamberoo Valley folk festival. This gave me pleasure on a number of counts. The most obvious ones were that, firstly, I happen to be a resident of the Jamberoo Valley and, secondly, I am the patron of the Illawarra Folk Club, the organisation that staged the festival. Apart from these personal considerations, the most impressive features were the large numbers of people who attended the two-day festival and the quality of the number of artists who performed there. Over the weekend several thousand people descended on our village of Jamberoo, the normal population of which is 400. Some stayed the weekend, while some came just for specific events. The local community of Jamberoo entered into the spirit of the weekend, with the parents and citizens association, the youth hall committee and local artists and potters contributing. The artists included John Williamson, Bandy Bill and Co from Inverell, a visiting scottish group, Rua, Aboriginal singer-songwriter Kevin Carmody, Gary Shearston, John Dengate, John Broomhall and many performers from both the Illawarra and the rest of New South Wales and Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The point to be made about folk festivals is that, unlike other types of musical events such as opera, rock or country, they are multi-faceted. Whereas these strands of our culture tend to be monodirectional-and I do not decry them in any way-their prime function is to entertain and display the expertise of the performers. On the other hand, as well as entertainment, folk festivals are about preserving our culture, about examining our past, about commenting on our present, and about recording a heritage that may not be based on monotonous mindlessness that one frequently picks up on commercial electronic media. This festival was no different in that it had workshops examining the language-`Keep the language alive and unique' was the cry of John Dengate and his workshop-Margaret Walters and Margaret Bradford looked at the roll of colonial women in song, Kevin Carmody looked at Aboriginal songwriting, Denis Kevans used verse to record contemporary social and political fables and Michael O'Sullivan taught us that anyone could be a songwriter. There were also the yarn spinners, the colonial dancers, the musicians, the songwriters, the instrument makers, the activities for the kids, the concerts and the Morris and Irish dancers and, most importantly, the audiences.

That so many people attended the festival was a credit to the organisers. It also showed that a large number of members of the public enjoy the cultural exchanges, the thought provoking songs and music that has not been siphoned through an electronic desk to the extent that the human being who creates the sound becomes secondary to the technology that blasts it out. People came despite the fact that folk music and life is largely ignored by the commercial media, whose rigid programming and reliance on computer printouts of rating surveys have left us with a monotonous and mindless uniformity that ignores the rich living culture that is being developed in Australia. I have been saddened to see the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) program That's Australia moved from a prime Saturday night slot to a late Wednesday night slot. It has been the only folk program on television for the last 15 years. I am heartened, however, by the success of Ian Macnamara's Australia All Over on Sunday morning, on which I heard you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Those of us with electorates outside the metropolitan area would be aware of the immense following this program has attracted.

While on the subject of the ABC, I congratulate our local radio station 2WN and its progressive and committed manager, Allen Clark. The success of Jamberoo was due in no small part to the promotion of folk music-particularly local folk music-by radio 2WN. I would add that 2WN under Allen Clark has fostered not only folk music but all local musical, cultural, social and political activities. It has become a true local station. Despite its limited resources, it is, I believe, a model for others to follow. Largely due to Allen's exertions, the festival was broadcast live on Friday night to all regional stations in New South Wales-a feat of programming and technology, the complexity of which few of us lay persons can comprehend. I have had many complimentary comments from members of this House about the program. They had received favourable comments from their constituents who had heard the live broadcasts. David Mulholland, from Radio National's On the wallaby track', made use of the ABC's outside broadcasting van during the weekend. He has recorded many of the events for future airplay on that excellent program.

The whole festival was conducted without large scale financial assistance from any government agency or private sponsor. There was no bowing to the political whims of commercial sponsors; nor was the festival subject to the bureaucratic scrutiny that is a requirement of government assistance. To conclude, I would like to say that I am proud to have such an event flourishing in the heartland of my electorate. It is a reminder that not all Australians are slaves to the imported culture--

TALK.START.PARA: —Before raising the issue that I want to talk about tonight, I point out to the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) that, while the Australian Broadcasting Corporation does some things very well, it is unfortunate that many people in the country-I receive many complaints about this-can no longer hear Parliament on the radio. SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to speak about recognition of an event that occurred some time ago. In the Vietnam war nearly 500 Australians gave their lives, but until recently those people had never been given any recognition and those who returned had never been given the reception that we have given to other people who served their country overseas. However, the Vietnam veterans served their country with as much distinction as any Australians in any theatre of war. It is pleasing, I guess in one way, that at long last some recognition is being given to these veterans. On 21 April I had the great pleasure to attend the first screening of a film in Portland. That film, The Long Road Home, produced in Portland, depicts not only some aspects of the Vietnam war but, more importantly, the reaction of those who served, both before they went to the war and since their return. It was a very moving experience which made one realise that the people who went to that war did so in good faith because they believed they were serving their country. They were not looking for any reward, but I am sure they were not expecting to find most Australians turning their backs on them when they returned. It was a very bitter pill for them to swallow and one that they found very difficult to adjust to when they returned.

I was very touched by this film, but it was also very interesting to see the reaction of the people in the film because they were also present at the screening. They were the ones who returned, albeit with some scars-both external and internal. The four men in particular who were interviewed in the film were Jim Murrell, Dave Cleary, Daryl McCombe and Selwyn Williams. Each one told his story and gave a very moving and realistic expression of how he was affected and how he had managed to readjust. In many ways, anyone who saw that film could not help feeling ashamed at the way that we have treated those servicemen since their return from that war.

This film, The Long Road Home, produced by Peter Corbett, is the right length for television but, regrettably, to date Australian television stations have shown little interest. However, it is being shown at the Cannes Film Festival this month and, hopefully, the film will gain the recognition that I believe it more than justly deserves because it captures the attitude of those real people who have come back and found what it is like to try to readjust. They happened to be called up and sent overseas to serve their country in a war in which they did not want to be involved but, nonetheless, they were prepared to do their duty. Naturally enough, the disappointment must have been immense when they returned home to find that Australia no longer wanted to know them.

I believe that the time has come for recognition. To date, I believe that the Government's efforts have been fairly miserable. I was pleased to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has announced that the Government will put forward $200,000 for a memorial. It has been planned to erect a memorial in Canberra for the Vietnam servicemen, particularly the 500 who gave their lives. The memorial will cost considerably more than $200,000, so I call on the Government to be a little bit more generous in belatedly recognising that these Australians served their country with as much distinction, valour and commitment as any Australian who has served overseas. I believe that their cause certainly deserves due recognition in a proper memorial in Canberra.
